questions.text:
If a person is asked the meaning of "Strike when the rod is hot", and they reply that, "It means that you should strike when the iron rod is hot to melt it because it is the most malleable then".
What aspect of their thinking is demonstrated?
questions.solution:
When the person is asked the meaning of the proverb, they could only answer in the literal sense, and not think what the proverb means metaphorically. This is called concrete thinking.

A person capable of abstract thinking would have answered the metaphorical meaning of the proverb given in the question (strike when the iron is hot), which is to take action when the opportunities are favourable.

 Concrete thinking  Abstract thinking
  • Develops first in childhood
  • Understand the literal meaning of a sentence/proverb
  • Focused on facts
  • Cannot compare and contrast different objects/situations
  • Think about a specific event/object individually.
  • Think about a situation in one particular way
  • Can think only about objects they have seen or situations they have experienced
  • Develops later in childhood gradually and emerges in adolescence
  • Understand the deeper meaning of a sentence/ proverb
  • Focused on concepts
  • Can compare and contrast and derive conclusions 
  • Can derive generalizations from a specific event/object.
  • Think about various aspects of a situation simultaneously
  • Can think about objects/situations that were never experienced by them or that do not exist in reality.

questions.text: What is the dose of dexamethasone given for fetal lung maturity?

choices.text: 4 doses of 6 mg given 12 hours apart

questions.solution:
The dosage of dexamethasone given for fetal lung maturity is 4 doses of 6 mg, which is given 12 hours apart. 

Maternal administration of glucocorticoids is advised in preterm labor when the period of gestation is less than 34 weeks. Intramuscular injection of either betamethasone or dexamethasone is given.

Dosage: 

  • Betamethasone(Betnesol): Two doses of 12 mg each, given 24 hours apart.
  • Dexamethasone: Four doses of 6 mg each, given every 12 hours.

This helps in fetal lung maturation and minimize the incidence of:

  • Respiratory distress syndrome
  • Intraventricular hemorrhage
  • Necrotizing enterocolitis

It is beneficial when the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours after the first dose.

questions.text: Identify the type of wound from the image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows irregular and ragged cut wounds over the palmar surface of the hands and fingers, which is suggestive of defense wounds.

Defense wounds are the wounds that occur as a result of the victim's attempt to save himself from an injury.

It can be active or passive. Active defense wounds occur when the victim tries to grasp the weapon, while passive wounds result when the victim raises the hands, arms, or legs in an attempt to protect the eyes, head, or neck.

The morphology of the wound depends upon the type of weapon and the attack. In a sharp injury due to a single-edged weapon, a single cut may be seen on the palm or the bends of fingers. In the case of a double-edged sharp weapon, cuts are seen on both the palm and fingers. The cuts are irregular in-depth and ragged.

The defense wounds signify homicide, and in females, they often indicate sexual assault. 

Other options:

Options B and C: Antemortem and postmortem wounds are of medicolegal importance while evaluating trauma. They can be differentiated by the following features:

Feature Antemortem wounds Postmortem wounds
Edges Swollen edges with wound gapes Closely approximated with no wound gapes 
Hemorrhage Arterial type of hemorrhage Venous hemorrhage
Spurting Spurting of blood seen with firmly coagulated blood No spurts and no clotting 
Vital reaction Inflammation and repair seen No signs of inflammation and repair

Option D: Hesitation cuts are a feature of self-inflicted wounds or suicide. It typically appears as multiple, small, and superficial wounds on the skin, at the beginning of an incised wound. The common sites are the throat, wrist, and front of the chest.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was incidentally diagnosed with a non-functional adrenal tumor of size 3 cm during his routine check-up. Subsequently, in about 3 months, the size of the tumor in MRI increases by about 40%. The next ideal step in the treatment of this patient would be:

choices.text: CT-guided fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the tumor

questions.solution:
From the given description, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is the ideal and definitive management in non-functional adrenal tumors, i.e, incidentalomas more than 4 cm in size. An increase in the size of the tumor by 40% indicates an increase in size by 1.2 cm. Thus, the total size of the tumor here is 4.2 cm. 

An adrenal incidentaloma is defined as a clinically unapparent adrenal lesion that is incidentally detected in imaging studies. The majority of these lesions are non-functional.  Secondary metastasis from breast, lung, and kidneys are seen in 2% of the patients. Functional tumors may present with Cushing's syndrome, phaeochromocytoma, Conn's syndrome, etc. These tumors can become malignant and the incidence increases 4-fold if the size of the lesion crosses 4 cm. 

Management of non-functional incidentalomas < 4cm is conservative with routine MRI surveillance every 3-6 months. If > 4cm, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is done.

 Other options - 

A. Hormonal assay studies are done in suspected functional tumours or patients presenting with symptoms. If positive, it should be managed accordingly. Observation is not a followed protocol unless they're not functional or benign. 

B. Fine-needle aspiration and biopsy is avoided as it is inconclusive to distinguish adrenal adenomas from carcinomas. It can be considered in suspected extra-adrenal secondary metastasis. Tests for pheochromocytoma should always be done before the procedure to avoid precipitating a hypertensive crisis.

C. Follow-up MRI with 3-6 months surveillance is done for non-functional tumors <4cm size.

  2. 45-year-old with no desire for menstruation/pregnancy
  3. 30-year-old in puerperial period
  4. 38-year-old with family complete but desires for menstruation.
  1. Fothergill's operation
  2. Cervicopexy
  3. Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair
  4.  Ring pessary
questions.solution:
Option C is correct. 

          Age/condition       Management

1) Nulliparous women with a desire for future pregnancy

ii.  Cervicopexy

2) 45-year-old with no desire for menstruation/pregnancy

iii.  Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

3) 30-year-old in puerperial period

 iv.  Ring pessary 

4) 38-year-old with family complete but desires for menstruation.

i.  Fothergill's operation

Sling operations are recommended in cases of nulliparous prolapse for those who wish to retain menstrual and child-bearing function. Mackenrodt’s and uterosacral ligaments of the uterus are strengthened, by using nylon or Dacron tapes as slings. Abdominal sling operations include abdominal wall cervicopexy, Shirodkar’s sling operation, Khanna’s abdominal sling operation, Virkud's sling operation, and Joshi's sling operation.

Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management of genital prolapse in women >40 years of age, those who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.

A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patients, patients in puerperium, and very elderly women unfit for surgery. It is used in adjunct with pelvic floor physiotherapy. Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. The first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform Valsalva's manoeuvre or cough and see if the pessary is in place. After being placed, they need to be changed every 3 months. 

Fothergill's repair also known as Manchester's operation is suitable for women under 40 years who are desirous of retaining their menstrual and reproductive functions. It involves anterior colporrhaphy with amputation of the cervix. The mackenrodt ligaments are sutured in the front of the cervix and colpoperineorrhaphy is done. It increases the risk of cervical incompetence leading to recurrent abortions and preterm deliveries. Shirodkar's modification of Fothergill's repair avoids cervical amputation, hence subsequent pregnancy complications are avoided.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient, an accident victim started developing difficulty in breathing. On examination, his BP was 80/40mmHg and pulses were feeble, JVP was found to be elevated with an absent y descent, and heart sounds were muffled. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated JVP -  Beck's triad suggests a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. The JVP finding most likely to be seen is prominent x descent and absent y descent.

Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space. It results in the obstruction of the blood flow into the ventricles.

This manifests as Beck's triad which consists of the following: 

  • Distended neck veins (due to decreased venous return)
  • Muffled heart sounds (fluid accumulation in the pericardial space)
  • Hypotension

The physical examination findings in a patient with cardiac tamponade are:

  • Tachycardia
  • Hypotension
  • Elevated JVP
  • Pulsus paradoxus

The chest wall movements will be normal. An eFAST is reliable and will show fluid in the pericardial space. A chest X-ray will show an enlarged heart shadow.

Cardiac tamponade can also be treated with open surgery procedures like sternotomy or left thoracotomy. This also allows for the heart to be repaired during the procedure.

questions.text: A 55 year old patient presented with chronic projectile vomiting and weight loss. What is the expected metabolic abnormality to be seen here ?

choices.text: Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypernatremia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hypercalcemia
Hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic acidosis with hyponatremia

questions.solution:
The expected metabolic abnormality to be seen in this patient is hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

The persistent vomiting results in these abnormalities along with paradoxical aciduria. 

  • Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).
  • Kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3- causing hyponatremia. However, loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone through the RAAS pathway.
  • The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions.
  • Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia.
  • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is called paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to the loss of HCl, and instead of compensating for that loss, the body loses more H+ ions through urine.

questions.text: Which intravenous anesthetic has the maximum incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Etomidate has the highest incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) among intravenous anesthetics.

Propofol has antiemetic properties thereby reducing PONV.

  • Myoclonus

questions.text: A grand multipara had continuous, moderate vaginal bleeding immediately after delivery. What could be the most probable cause of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum haemorrhage in a grand multipara.

Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Contraction helps to arrest bleeding from vessels at the placental implantation site.

Types of PPH:

  1. Primary/early: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Uterine atony is the most common cause of primary PPH.
  2. Secondary/late: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Retained placenta is the most common cause.

The risk factors for atonic uterus include:

  1. Primiparity or grand multiparity
  2. Previous PPH
  3. Overdistended uterus as in multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, macrosomia
  4. Precipitate labour
  5. Prolonged labour
  6. Uterine malformations
  7. Uterine fibroid
  8. Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin
  9. Placental abnormalities like placenta previa, accreta, increta, percreta, or abruptio placenta
  10. Obesity
  11. Age >40 years

Note: Uterine inversion occurs rarely and causes secondary PPH.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with chest pain and breathlessness which increases on lying down and is relieved on sitting upright. On examination, heart sounds are muffled. His chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and X-ray appearance of the money bag heart is suggestive of pericardial effusion.

Plain PA chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette. There is effacement of the normal cardiac borders, development of a ‘flask’ or ‘water bottle’ cardiac configuration, and bilateral hilar overlay which are features of pericardial effusion. It is also known as money bag or leather bottle-shaped heart.

Pericardial effusions occur when excess fluid collects in the pericardial space (a normal pericardial sac contains approximately 30-50 mL of fluid).

Investigation of choice: Echocardiography.

Signs on plain radiograph include:

  • Globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow giving a water bottle configuration.
  • Lateral CXR may show a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line directly behind the sternum (paracardial fat) anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical lucent line (epicardial fat) posteriorly; this is known as the Oreo cookie sign.

questions.text: A patient after a motor vehicle accident develops breathing difficulty. On examination, there are decreased breath sounds on the right side, and the trachea is shifted to the left. Heart sounds are normal. There is a dull note on percussion. The chest X-ray is shown below. What will be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Decreased breath sounds, tracheal deviation to the opposite side, dull note on percussion, and the chest X-ray showing blunting of the costophrenic angle and opacification is suggestive of massive hemothorax. The next step of management that can be done for this patient is intercostal drainage tube(ICD) placement.

Massive hemothorax occurs when more than 1500 mL of blood, equivalent to one-third or more of the patient's blood volume, rapidly accumulates in the chest cavity. This condition is typically caused by a penetrating injury that damages major blood vessels, although it can also be the result of blunt trauma.

In patients with massive hemothorax, the neck veins may appear flat due to severe hypovolemia, or they may be distended if there is a concurrent tension pneumothorax. If a patient is in shock and exhibits an absence of breath sounds or dullness upon percussion on one side of the chest, it suggests the presence of a massive hemothorax.

The initial management of massive hemothorax involves simultaneous resuscitation to restore blood volume and decompression of the chest cavity. This is achieved by establishing large-diameter intravenous lines, administering crystalloid fluids, and initiating transfusion of blood at the earliest opportunity. A single chest tube with a diameter of 28-32 French is inserted, typically at the fifth intercostal space, just anterior to the midaxillary line. Volume restoration is rapidly continued while the chest cavity is decompressed.

The immediate return of 1500 mL or greater volume of blood typically signifies the urgent requirement for thoracotomy. Patients who initially show an output of less than 1500 mL of fluid but continue to bleed may also necessitate thoracotomy.

Needle thoracostomy and open thoracostomy are done in cases of tension pneumothorax. Here, the patients present with distended neck veins, decreased breath sounds, tracheal deviation to the opposite side, and hyper-resonant note on percussion. 

Pericardiocentesis is done in cases of cardiac tamponade. Here, the patients present with distended neck veins, normal breath sounds, and muffled heart sounds. There is no mediastinal shift here.

questions.text:
A resident is doing an abdominal examination in a primigravida. Sequentially arrange the respective uses of Leopold's First maneuver, Leopold's second maneuver, Leopold's third maneuver, and Leopold's fourth maneuver in the corresponding order
  1. Determine the degree of descent
  2. Confirmation of fetal presentation
  3. Determine the fetal orientation
  4. Determine which fetal pole occupies the fundus.
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 4, 3, 2, 1:

Leopold First maneuvre - Determine which fetal pole occupies the fundus

Leopold second maneuver - Determine the fetal orientation

Leopold third maneuver - Confirmation of fetal presentation

Leopold fourth maneuver - Determine the degree of descent

Leopold’s first maneuver (fundal grip) is used to determine which fetal pole occupies the fundus.

Leopold’s second maneuver (lateral grip) can be used to determine the fetal orientation based on whether the back is facing anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly. The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen and gentle deep pressure is exerted. The fetal back is felt as a hard-resistant structure and the fetal limbs are felt as multiple small irregular parts.

Leopold’s third maneuver (Pawlik’s grip) helps to confirm fetal presentation. It is done by grasping the lower part of the maternal abdomen with the thumb and fingers of one hand. The palpation of a hard and round mass indicates that the presenting part is the fetal head. A movable mass suggests that the presenting part is not engaged. If the presenting part is breech, it is felt as a large nodular mass.

Leopold’s fourth maneuver (pelvic grip) helps to determine the degree of descent. The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of bias in a case-control study?
questions.solution:
Random error is a type of error in epidemiological studies that is difficult to eliminate and it is different from bias. Random error is when a value of the sample measurement diverges - due to chance alone - from that of the true population value, whereas bias comes under the category of systematic errors.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

  • Bias due to confounding: It can be removed by matching.
  • Memory or recall bias as cases and controls may not be able to recall specifics about their history.
  • Selection bias: Cases and controls may not be representative of the population or there may be systematic differences between both.
  • Berkesonian bias: This type of selection bias occurs in hospital cases and controls as the admission rates for people with different diseases may differ.
  • Interviewer’s bias: If the interviewer knows the hypothesis and who the cases are, he/she may interview the cases more thoroughly than the controls. It can be eliminated by double blinding.
  • Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias: It is due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. For example, a case-control study is carried out to study the relation between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI), being cases interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for the rebound effect seen with carbon monoxide poisoning?

choices.text: Binding of carbon monoxide to myoglobin
Binding of carbon monoxide to hemoglobin
Conversion of hemoglobin from T state to R state

questions.solution:
Rebound effect in carbon monoxide poisoning is due to binding of carbon monoxide to myoglobin. 

About 15% of CO present in extracellular tissues combines with myoglobin. A rebound effect with delayed return of symptoms is due to late release of CO from myoglobin with subsequent binding to hemoglobin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old teacher underwent parotidectomy following which she developed lower lip paralysis. This probably occurred because of an injury to which of the following structures?

choices.text: Buccal branch of the facial nerve

questions.solution:
Lower lip paralysis occurs when there is an injury to the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve. 

Branches of the facial nerve are:

  • Temporal
  • Zygomatic
  • Buccal
  • Marginal mandibular
  • Cervical

The facial nerve passes through the parotid gland, hence it might be injured during parotidectomy.

In contrast to this, the upper lip is supplied by buccal branches of the facial nerve.

Complications of parotidectomy include hematoma formation, infection, deformity (unsightly scarring and retromandibular hollowing), temporary/permanent facial weakness, sialocele, facial numbness, permanent numbness of the earlobe due to great auricular nerve transection and Frey's syndrome.

questions.text: A 51-year-old lady presents with complaints of a mass in the right breast. The examination finding is shown below. Fixed internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes are palpable on the same side. The mass is malignant without any metastasis. What is the TNM staging in this lady?
questions.solution:
This given clinical scenario in this woman with peau d’orange of the breast suggests her staging is T4b N3b M0

  • Tumour of any size with overlying skin involvement (Peau d'orange appearance) - T4b
  • Ipsilateral fixed internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes - N3b
  • No distant metastasis - M0

The term peau d’orange describes the orange-peel appearance of the skin. The dermal lymphatic blockade gives rise to edema in the breast. The sweat glands and hair follicles get buried due to the edema resulting in a typical orange peel appearance. Infiltration of the ligaments of Cooper results in dimpling of the skin. Infiltration of the lactiferous glands gives rise to retraction of the nipple. Spread into the chest wall results in fixation of the breast into the chest wall. This leads to restricted mobility of the breast

questions.text: A young female patient is undergoing evaluation for infertility. The cervical mucus shows the following appearance on microscopy. During which phase of the menstrual cycle is the given finding seen?

choices.text: Estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle

questions.solution:
The image shows a characteristic ferning pattern of cervical mucus seen during the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle. 

The characteristics of cervical mucous changes under the influence of estrogen and progesterone. During the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle, the cervical mucus is thin and stretchy due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus which shows the characteristic pattern seen above. This pattern disappears once ovulation has taken place due to the activity of progesterone. If previously present, its disappearance is presumptive evidence of corpus luteum activity.  

At the time of ovulation, the mucus becomes thin, watery, and clear that can be stretched up to 10cm. This is called spinnbarkeit or thread test and is presumptive of ovulation. During the progesterone phase, the mucus becomes thick and tenacious, impermeable to the sperms.

Other signs of ovulation are

  • An increase in basal body temperature(BBT) after ovulation due to the thermogenic action of the hormone progesterone. 
  • Urinary LH peak (increase in LH) is usually seen 1 day prior to ovulation.
  • The growth of ovarian follicles is 20 mm or more in size on USG at the time of ovulation.

The menstrual cycle consists of three phases: the menstrual phase, the proliferative phase, and the secretory, or progestational, phase

The menstrual phase is characterized by the discharge of blood and endometrial debris from the vagina due to the withdrawal of progesterone and the degeneration of the corpus luteum (CL).

The proliferative phase is estrogen-dominant and lasts from the end of menstruation to ovulation. It results in the proliferation of endometrial glands and thickened endometrium.

The secretory or progestational phase is progesterone dominant which converts the thickened, estrogen-primed endometrium to a richly vascularized, glycogen-filled tissue for early nourishment of a developing embryo. If fertilization and implantation do not occur, the corpus luteum degenerates and a new follicular phase and menstrual phase begin again.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is being evaluated for bleeding per vagina. She attained menopause at the age of 47. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Ovarian Follicular cysts are least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding. They are usually asymptomatic unless they rupture, hemorrhage or the ovary undergoes torsion which would manifest as an acute abdomen. They occur when there is the failure of absorption of fluid in an incompletely developed follicle or anovulation. 

Postmenopausal bleeding is diagnosed when there is bleeding per vagina after 6 months of amenorrhoea after the age of 40 (menopausal age). 

Causes of postmenopausal bleeding include: 

  • Genital tract trauma (Option A)
  • Cervical erosion, inflammation, polyp, or ulcer
  • Uterus - endometritis, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma (Option C), polyp, or sarcoma
  • Fallopian tube malignancy
  • Ovarian tumors such as Brenner tumor, granulosa cell tumor (Option D)
  • Hypertension and blood dyscrasia
  • Urinary tract trauma, bladder carcinoma
  • Hemorrhoid, anal fissures, and rectal cancers confused as bleeding per vagina
  • Use of estrogens as hormone replacement therapy, tamoxifen.

questions.text: The image shown below is commonly seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an exclamation mark hair sign which is a characteristic feature seen in Alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes nonscarring patches of hair loss. It is a T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed patients.

The most characteristic lesion initially is a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia which has short extractable broken hairs called exclamation mark hair.

Other options:

Option B: Patients with telogen effluvium demonstrate empty follicles and regrowing hairs of normal thickness on dermoscopy.

Option C: Netherton syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. Patients with this disease present with lustreless, dry, short hair. On trichoscopy, patients may have a characteristic bamboo hair defect due to the collapse of the distal hair shaft into the proximal hair shaft secondary to defective keratinization.

Option D: Primary cicatricial alopecias are inflammatory disorders that lead to permanent hair loss

  2. Enuresis
  3. Hesitancy
  4. Frequency

Urgency, enuresis and frequency are storage symptoms.

Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) can be classified as:

Storage Voiding
  • Frequency (earliest symptom in BPH)
  • Nocturia
  • Urgency
  • Urge incontinence
  • Nocturnal incontinence (enuresis)
  • Hesitancy
  • Poor flow
  • Intermittent stream
  • Dribbling

questions.text: A patient presents with a painless swelling of the neck. The histology of the tissue is as given in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The slide shows the picture of Hashimoto thyroiditis, with

  • Follicular destruction
  • Reduced colloid with increased interstitial connective tissue
  • Small lymphocyte and plasma cell infiltration
  • A well-developed germinal center may be seen

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual & progressive thyroid failure.

Clinical features:

  • Most prevalent between 45 and 65 years of age
  • More common in females
  • Painless enlargement of the thyroid
  • Hashitoxicosis: When the auto-antibodies attack and damage the follicles, there is a sudden release of thyroid hormones from these follicles. Thus, leading to a transient phase of thyrotoxicosis.
  • Hypothyroidism: Since the follicles are damaged and cannot form the hormones anymore, these patients tend to be in a state of hypothyroidism.

Diagnosis:

  • T3 and T4 are low
  • TSH is raised
  • Autoantibodies against:
    • Thyroid receptors
    • Thyroid peroxidase (TPO)
    • Thyroglobulin

These patients are managed with thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

In patients with long-standing goiter, there is a risk of compressive features and development of thyroid lymphoma. Such cases can be treated with total thyroidectomy.

questions.text: An obstetrician performs the following procedure for labor induction in a patient. Which of the following is false about the reflex elicited here?

choices.text: Occurs due to pressure at the external os of cervix
It is associated with increased level of PGF2α
Artificial rupture of membranes initiates this reflex
It is an example of positive feedback mechanism

questions.solution:
Stripping of membranes is being depicted in the image, which elicits the Ferguson reflex. It is also known as the fetal ejection reflex and is seen due to the pressure at the internal os of the cervix.

Other options:

  • It is associated with an increase in blood levels of a prostaglandin F2α metabolite, also known as dinoprost. This is released due to mechanical stretching of the internal os. This enhances the uterine activity and causes release of more prostaglandins. It is an example of a positive feedback mechanism.
  • The Ferguson reflex can be initiated by various means, including artificial rupture of the amniotic membranes (amniotomy). When the amniotic sac is ruptured, it can lead to cervical stretching and stimulate the reflex, which, in turn, can result in uterine contractions.
  • The Ferguson reflex is indeed an example of a positive feedback mechanism. In positive feedback, the response to a stimulus amplifies the stimulus rather than counteracting it. In the case of the Ferguson reflex, the initial stretching of the cervix leads to uterine contractions, which, in turn, lead to further cervical stretching and stronger contractions, ultimately culminating in childbirth. This is a classic example of a positive feedback loop.

questions.text: Under McNaughten's rule, which of the following criteria is not valid to clear a mentally unsound person of all responsibility?

choices.text: Psychiatric illness while committing the crime
Inability to understand that the act is wrong

questions.solution:
The criterion of the presence of uncontrollable impulse is not included in McNaughten's rule. Therefore, it is not a valid criterion to clear a mentally unsound person of all criminal responsibility.

McNaughten's rule is followed by the British Courts of law to examine the liability of a mentally unsound person who has committed a crime. Sec. 84 IPC (BNS Section 22) is the Indian adaptation of this rule. 

McNaughten's rule forms the basis of the legal test of insanity/the 'right or wrong' test. It states that a mentally unsound person is cleared of all criminal responsibility for the crime committed if the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of evidence of psychiatric illness.
  • Existence of psychiatric illness at the time of the commission of the crime.
  • Psychiatric illness is of such a degree that the person does not have the ability to understand the wrongness of the act, i.e., impaired intellectual ability. 

McNaughten's rule decides a person's soundness of mind based on the presence or absence of intellectual ability. However, it fails to consider any impairments in the person's emotional state or the presence of any uncontrollable/ irresistible impulses while committing the act.

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient presents with chest pain and dyspnea following an alcohol binge. His ECG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with ECG showing narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals and no distinct P waves is suggestive of atrial fibrillation.

Atrial fibrillation is the most common sustained arrhythmia. There is rapid and irregular atrial activation which is transmitted through the atrioventricular node. The conducted ventricular rate is usually rapid and irregularly irregular. It can vary from 110-160 beats/minute. A pulse deficit is an important clinical finding associated with the condition. This arises due to preload reduction. 

Symptoms include palpitations, fatigue, presyncope, and dyspnea. An ECG shows the absence of P waves. 

In acute atrial fibrillation with hemodynamic instability, electrical or chemical cardioversion is the first step. The latter is done by intravenous administration of class III antiarrhythmic - ibutilide. In a stable patient, ventricular rate control is the primary aim. This is done by intravenous or oral administration of beta-blockers. Calcium channel blockers such as verapamil and diltiazem can also be used. 

If the current episode duration is >48 hours, cardioversion can precipitate thromboembolic complications. In such cases, cardioversion should be carried out only after 3 weeks of anticoagulation. It has to be continued for 4 weeks after cardioversion. Another option is to evaluate the presence of a thrombus in the left atrial appendage. This can be done either by transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) or high-resolution CT.

If the duration is <48 hours and there are no high-risk factors, cardioversion can be done. The CHA2DS2-VASc scoring system is used to assess stroke risk. 

Warfarin is recommended in patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves who present with atrial fibrillation. In mitral stenosis, thrombi arise frequently from the dilated left atrium. Atrial fibrillation in the absence of mitral stenosis is known as nonvalvular atrial fibrillation. Oral factor Xa inhibitors such as apixaban, edoxaban, or rivaroxaban can be used in such cases.

  • C3: edema
  • C4a: pigmentation or eczema (including malleolar flare)
  • C4b: lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.  Lipodermatosclerosis (LDS) refers to chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the skin and subcutaneous tissues. This is seen as a tight, contracted, 'woody leg' on examination. Atrophie blanche refers to localized areas of white, atrophic skin surrounded by telangiectasia and pigmentation.
  • C5: healed venous ulcer
  • C6: active venous ulcer

Each clinical class is further characterized depending on whether the patient is symptomatic (S) or asymptomatic (A).

Patients complain of a sensation of heaviness, burning, and aching over the affected area or whole limb, that increases throughout the day or on prolonged standing. Compression and elevation relieve the symptoms.

Diagnosis is mainly using duplex ultrasound. MR venography or intravenous ultrasound(IVUS) may be used occasionally.

Treatment is achieved using modalities such as compression, laser ablation, endothermal ablation, radiofrequency ablation, endovenous glue, ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy, open surgery, etc.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with post-menopausal bleeding. Ultrasonography revealed a mass with feeding vessel as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Visualisation of a feeding vessel on colour doppler is characteristic of an endometrial polyp.

These are homogeneous, isoechoic lesions that are continuous with the endometrium and preserve the endomyometrial interface. They may be centrally cystic, corresponding to dilated fluid-filled glands.

Benign endometrial polyps may occur at all ages, with their greatest prevalence after age 50. They are a common cause of postmenopausal bleeding.

questions.text: A young man presents with a sudden onset of severe headache, dizziness, breathlessness, and blurring of vision while trekking on a mountain at an altitude of 5000 meters. He is unable to climb any further. Which of the following indicates the development of high-altitude cerebral edema?
questions.solution:
Altered mental status is a clinical finding indicative of the development of high-altitude cerebral edema. 

At high altitudes, the partial pressure of oxygen in the atmosphere is low. When people ascend to high altitudes hypoxia causes systemic arteriolar dilatation. Consequently, the capillary pressure rises with increased transudation of fluid into the brain tissue and lungs. This results in cerebral edema and pulmonary edema respectively.

Pathophysiology: Vasogenic edema occurs due to the leaking of proteins and water through the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Causes of increased BBB permeability include:

  • Mechanical factors: loss of autoregulation and increased capillary pressure due to increased sympathetic activity (option D).
  • Increased chemical mediators of permeability: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) (option C), nitric oxide, and cytokines (option A).

Patients with cerebral edema usually present with:

  • Headache
  • Altered mental status (progressive decline of mental function and consciousness)
  • Papilledema leading to a blurring of vision
  • Breathlessness (due to hypoxia)
  • Nausea and vomiting.

Treatment involves administration of oxygen, descent to a lower altitude, and administration of acetazolamide. Acetazolamide counteracts hypoxia by stimulating respiration and also reduces the formation of cerebrospinal fluid, thereby reducing intracranial tension. Glucocorticoids are administered as well.

Portable hyperbaric chambers are increasingly being used in the treatment of high-altitude illnesses when rapid descent is not possible. These chambers are available in armed forces hospitals in high-altitude areas.

Related Pearl: Acclimatization to high altitude

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of sarcoidosis presents with skin lesions shown in the image below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given condition is lupus pernio.

Lupus pernio is a cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis. It involves the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory condition with multisystem involvement. The most common organs affected are the lungs, liver, eye, and skin. The most widely accepted etiological hypothesis is an inflammatory response to an infectious or non-infectious trigger in a susceptible host.

There are two syndromes that are associated with the condition.

  • Lofgren's syndrome is characterized by erythema nodosum and hilar adenopathy. Periarticular arthritis can also be seen.
  • Mikulicz syndrome is bilateral involvement of parotid, submaxillary, and sublingual glands. 

The most common presenting features are cough, dyspnea, fever, night sweats, and weight loss.  The eyes can be involved in the form of anterior uveitis, photophobia, dry eyes, and blurred vision. Neurological involvement in the form of myelopathy, basilar meningitis, and facial nerve paralysis. Skin involvement can be seen as maculopapular lesions, keloid formation, ad subcutaneous nodules. Lupus pernio refers to the skin involvement of the bridge of the nose, periocular region, and cheeks and points to a chronic state.

Histopathological examination reveals non-necrotizing granulomas made of macrophages and giant cells. Calcium and protein concretions known as Schaumann bodies and stellate inclusions called asteroid bodies may be seen within the giant cells. 

Chest X-ray is preferred to stage lung involvement. CT features include peribronchial thickening and reticular nodular changes.

Glucocorticoids are the drug of choice for management.

Other options:

Option A- Lupus vulgaris is a manifestation of cutaneous tuberculosis.

Option C- Heliotrope rash presents as violaceous lesions around eyelids. It is seen in dermatomyositis.

Option D- Erysipelas presents as erythematous raised lesions with sharply demarcated edges. It is caused due to streptococcal skin infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Kallman syndrome -  hypothalamic hypogonadism is a cause of primary amenorrhea, not secondary. 

Primary amenorrhoea: is defined as an absence of menstruation by the age of 15 years. At age 13 years, if no menses have occurred and there is a complete absence of secondary sexual characteristics such as breast development, evaluation for primary amenorrhea should begin.. Mullerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome), androgen insensitivity syndrome, and Turner syndrome present with primary amenorrhea. 

Kallman syndrome is associated with a low or absent GnRH. The condition is characterized by anosmia, hypogonadism, infertility, and absent, or partial pubertal maturation. Treatment includes GnRH, pituitary hormones, estrogen, and progestogen to induce menstruation.

Secondary amenorrhoea refers to the absence of menses for more than three months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or six months in girls or women who had irregular menses. Pregnancy is the most common cause of secondary amenorrhea. Sheehan's syndrome and Asherman's syndrome are other examples.

The flowcharts summarize the various causes of primary amenorrhea and the investigations undertaken for evaluation.

  • Posterior column: pedicles, laminae, facets and posterior ligamentous complex

questions.text: A hypertensive pregnant woman presents with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum, and loss of fetal movements. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum, and loss of fetal movements in a hypertensive pregnant woman points to the diagnosis of placental abruption.  

Premature separation of a normally implanted placenta is placental abruption. Hypertension is a very important etiological factor in abruption. 

The hemorrhage into decidua basalis causes separation and compression of the placenta. This leads to a compromise of circulation to fetus, leading to fetal distress. The bleeding may escape through the cervix to cause external hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman suffers from emotional lability, fatigue, bloating, headache, sleeplessness, and breast tenderness about 10 days prior to her menses. These symptoms get relieved once she menstruates. All of the following are recommended in the management of this condition except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of Premenstrual syndrome (PMS). All the above-mentioned measures are recommended in the management of PMS except caffeine. Foods and beverages rich in sugar and caffeine can aggravate premenstrual symptoms in some women and are generally avoided. 

Premenstrual syndrome can be managed by dietary changes and lifestyle modifications like yoga, exercises and relaxation activities. Pharmacological therapy includes the usage of primrose oil, vitamin B1, vitamin B6, vitamin E, calcium and magnesium supplements.

Symptoms can be alleviated by the use of prostaglandin inhibitors (ibuprofen and naproxen ), Selective Serotonin Reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) like fluoxetine, GABA antagonists and anxiolytics such as alprazolam. Danazol, bromocriptine and GnRH analogues can be used to reduce breast pain. OCPs with spironolactone and Mirena IUCD can also be used.

Premenstrual Syndrome (PMS) is a symptom complex associated with ovulatory cycles. It occurs 7 to 14 days prior to menstruation and spontaneously resolves after menses. It occurs in the luteal phase of the cycle. When this symptom complex causes significant impairment, a diagnosis of premenstrual dysphoric disorder(PMDD) is made according to DSM-5.

Symptoms include

  • Pain:- Headache, breast pain, abdominal cramps, muscle stiffness, backache and generalized body ache.
  • Water retention:- Breast volume increase, bloating and weight gain.
  • Behavioural changes:- Low performance, difficulty in concentration, irritability, depression, forgetfulness, low judgement, anxiety, loneliness, feeling like crying, hostility, increased appetite and cravings and sleeplessness.
  • Autonomic changes:- Dizziness, faintness, nausea, vomiting and hot flushes.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to OPD with complaints of pain over the forearm. On detailed examination, several wounds with cigarettes burns are found. X-ray showed a spiral fracture of the radius. Which of the following is least likely seen in this condition?

choices.text: Multiple injuries at same stage of healing

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of battered baby syndrome. The classical feature of this condition is injuries inflicted are of different ages and in different stages of healing. This is due to the repetitive nature of child abuse.

A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian, there may also be deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection.

This syndrome must be considered in any child:

  • In whom the degree and type of injury varies with the history given
  • When injuries are of different ages and in different stages of healing
  • When there is a purposeful delay in seeking medical attention despite serious injury
  • Who exhibits evidence of fracture of any bone, subdural hematoma, failure to thrive, soft tissue swelling or skin bruising
  • Who dies suddenly

Skeletal survey, which includes the following, should be done in a case of suspected child abuse:

  • AP views of the entire skeleton
  • Dedicated views of hands and feet
  • Lateral views of the appendicular skeleton, skull, and spine

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient is found to have features of chronic myeloid leukemia in the peripheral smear. What is most likely to be found on physical examination?
questions.solution:
Splenomegaly is most likely to be found on physical examination. 

Clinical features of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) are:

  • The majority of the patients with CML are asymptomatic. They are suspected during the routine blood tests when they have elevated white blood cells count. When symptomatic, they are usually the manifestations of anemia and splenomegaly. They include easy fatigability, decreased tolerance to exertion, abdominal pain, etc. 
  • Increased number of WBCs and platelets in the blood might lead to hyperviscosity of the blood leading to cardiovascular and cerebrovascular events.
  • Increased cell metabolism might lead to night sweats, weight loss, and hyperuricemia.

Haemoglobin - 10g/dl,  WBC count - 1,50,000/cu.mm and platelet count is 2,50,000/cu.mm. Immunohistochemical observations shows CD19+, CD20+, CD21+, C22+, CD23(-),CD 5+. questions.text: Acromegaly is characterized by all of the following clinical conditions except ______
questions.solution:
Microglossia(i.e small tongue) is not a clinical feature of acromegaly. Rather, macroglossia is seen in acromegaly.

Features of acromegaly due to increased GH:

  • Abnormally increased bone growth: Frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, Mandibular enlargement with prognathism.
  • Soft tissue swelling: Increased heel pad thickness, Characteristic coarse facial features, large fleshy tongue(macroglossia).
  • Cardiovascular system: Coronary heart disease, cardiomyopathy with arrhythmias, left ventricular hypertrophy.
  • Upper airway obstruction with sleep apnea.
  • Diabetes mellitus develops in 25% of patients (as GH counteracts the action of insulin)
  • Increased risk of colon polyps and mortality from colonic malignancy

Other commonly encountered clinical features include hyperhidrosis, a deep and hollow-sounding voice, oily skin, arthropathy, kyphosis, carpal tunnel syndrome, proximal muscle weakness, acanthosis nigricans, and skin tags.

questions.text: All of the following are contraindications of LP except?

choices.text: Local skin infection at the site of LP

questions.solution:
The presence of skin infection near the site of the LP increases the risk of carrying the infection into the CSF with the LP needle. Thus, infection at the potential LP site is a contraindication to performing a lumbar puncture at that area.

Perhaps the more worrisome contraindication to lumbar puncture is the suspicion of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) due to a cerebral mass lesion. In the presence of a potential brain tumor, cerebral hemorrhage, cavernous sinus thrombosis, brain abscesses, epidural or subdural hematomas , patients are at increased risk of deteriorating neurologically with LP. As the space-occupying lesion grows, ICP rises. When lumbar puncture is performed in these patients, a low-pressure shunt is formed at the site of LP where CSF can escape.

As the CSF pressure drops in the spinal column, CSF and brain mass may then shift towards the low-pressure outlet (the LP site). This may lead to either trans-tentorial or uncal herniation and acute neurological deterioration.

Patients with increased ICP from mass lesions often display decreased levels of consciousness, focal neurological signs or papilledema on physical exam. Any of these findings make lumbar puncture contraindicated until further evaluation can be undertaken.

As with most invasive procedures, uncorrected coagulopathy is a contraindication to LP. This includes those on heparin, coumadin, or with clotting defects such as disseminated intravascular coagulation, hemophilia or thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient with hypertension presented with a sudden tearing type of chest pain. A  CECT chest was done and is given below. What is the preferred treatment option for this patient?

choices.text: Medical management with blood pressure control
Further diagnostic workup with transesophageal echocardiography

questions.solution:
The patient seems to be having an aortic dissection and CT chest indicates a Stanford Type A aortic dissection from the aortic root. He requires urgent surgical management.

The Stanford classification is used to separate aortic dissections into those that need surgical repair, and those that usually require only medical management. The Stanford classification divides dissections by the most proximal involvement.

Type A is when ascending aorta and arch are affected. It requires urgent surgical management and may result in:

  • Coronary artery occlusion
  • Aortic incompetence
  • Rupture into the pericardial sac with resulting cardiac tamponade

Type B begins beyond brachiocephalic vessels and dissection commences distal to the left subclavian artery affecting only the descending aorta. In these patients, initial treatment is medical management with blood pressure control.

The DeBakey classification divides dissections into:

  • Type I: involves ascending and descending aorta ( Stanford A)
  • Type II: involves ascending aorta only ( Stanford A)
  • Type III: involves descending aorta only, commencing after the origin of the left subclavian artery ( Stanford B)

Further diagnostic workup with TEE(transesophageal echocardiography) or MRA (magnetic resonance angiography) is not required as CT is showing ascending aorta dissection.

questions.text: In the following flowchart representing the natural history of disease, the duration between points A to B is called?
questions.solution:
The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the final critical point of diagnosis (point B) is called Screening time.

Screening is the search for unrecognized diseases or defects in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applicable tests or procedures. It must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis (point C in the image).

This ensures the success of any treatment in reversing the disease process. The final critical point (point B in the image) is the stage beyond which treatment would be unsuccessful or there would be permanent damage.

The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C) is called lead time.

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

The most appropriate management for a patient with a gunshot wound to the anterior abdominal wall with a breach of the peritoneum is laparotomy.

The incidence of significant injury to the intraperitoneal organs increases manifold when there is a breach of the peritoneum due to any penetrating trauma injury. The indications for doing laparotomy in patients with penetrating abdominal wounds include:

  • Gunshot wound which breaches the peritoneum
  • Evisceration
  • Bleeding from the stomach, rectum, or genitourinary tract following penetrating trauma
  • Peritonitis
  • Free air in the peritoneal cavity

questions.text: The cornerstone of treatment for a patient of dengue with warning signs is:
questions.solution:
The mainstay of treatment for a patient of dengue with warning signs is IV fluids.

The main pathology in dengue is plasma leakage resulting in intravascular volume depletion and thereby shock. So, supportive management with continuous infusion of crystalloid IV fluids remains the primary modality of treatment in these patients. And often patients respond well to supportive management.

Platelet transfusion is limited to patients with severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/mm3) and active bleeding.

FFP and cryoglobulins are not the preferred treatment modality in dengue.

Warning signs in dengue include 

  • Abdominal pain or tenderness
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Clinical fluid accumulation (ascites, pleural effusion)
  • Mucosal bleeding
  • Lethargy or restlessness
  • Hepatomegaly >2 cm
  • Increase in hematocrit concurrent with a rapid decrease in platelet count

Inpatient management is advised for all patients with dengue with warning signs.

questions.text: The absence of the SRY gene results in which of the following?

questions.solution:
The absence of the SRY gene results in the development of the ovaries and the Mullerian system.

In this situation, the gonads will develop into ovaries and the Mullerian duct will differentiate into the uterus, fallopian tubes, and the upper part of the vagina. The master gene responsible for this is the WNT4 gene.

The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome, which has a sex-determining region called the SRY gene.

If the Y chromosome is present, the protein called testis determining factor produced by the SRY gene will lead to the development of testis as the gonads. The Sertoli cells of the testis will then produce Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS; also known as Anti-Müllerian hormone, AMH) that will cause the Müllerian ducts to regress.

questions.text: Feeding is done through the given method. Which of the following is not a complication of this?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a central line. Pneumothorax, osteoporosis, and refeeding syndrome are likely complications in patients receiving total parenteral nutrition through a central line. Aspiration pneumonia is more common in enteral feeding and can be prevented by placing the patient in a semi-recumbent position while feeding.

Complications of enteral nutrition are as follows: 

  1. Tube-related (most common): Malposition, displacement, blockage, breakage/leakage, local complications (e.g. erosion of skin/mucosa)
  2. Gastrointestinal: Diarrhoea, bloating, nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, aspiration, constipation
  3. Metabolic/biochemical: Electrolyte disorders, vitamin, mineral, and trace element deficiencies, drug interactions
  4. Infective: Exogenous (handling contamination) and endogenous (patient)

Other options:

Option A: Refeeding syndrome is a significant metabolic complication of both parenteral and enteral feeding. It occurs days after feeding is commenced in patients who have been severely malnourished. The major pathological process is hypophosphatemia which causes fluid and electrolyte shifts between the intra- and extracellular compartments.

Option B: Osteoporosis and osteomalacia are complications of long-term parenteral nutrition and may lead to fractures or kidney stones. Calcium, phosphate, vitamin D supplementation, and bisphosphonates can help prevent as well as treat this complication.

Option C: Pneumothorax is the most common complication of line insertion and most commonly occurs during the insertion of subclavian lines. It is managed by insertion of a chest drain.

questions.text: The image below shows a pressure sore. Which stage does this belong to ?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pressure sore with extensive tissue destruction, including damage to the muscle layer and thus it belongs to stage 4.

Pressure sores also referred known as bed sores, pressure ulcers and decubitus ulcers are ulcers that occur due to prolonged pressure on certain sites thereby leading to tissue necrosis. The commonest sites involved are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral >medial), and occiput. Paraplegic patients, elderly patients, and severely ill patients are at a higher risk of developing pressure sores.

They are staged as:

  • Stage 1 - Erythema with no blanching and no breach in the epidermis.
  • Stage 2- Partial-thickness skin loss with epidermal and dermal involvement.
  • Stage 3- Full-thickness skin loss with intact fascia but the involvement of the subcutaneous tissue.
  • Stage 4- Full-thickness skin loss extending to the fascia with massive tissue destruction and involvement of muscle, bone, tendon, or joint. 

Management is primarily proper skin care with pressure dispersion cushions, air-fluidized beds, and urinary or fecal diversion if required. Patients who are bed-bound should be turned once in 2 hours. Those in a wheelchair should lift themselves off the seat for 10 seconds every 10 minutes.

Surgery is the last resort and is done after a proper initial debridement and vacuum-assisted closure. Vacuum-assisted closure is a wound closure technique in which negative pressure is applied to the wound which leads to a decrease in edema. This hastens the debridement and formation of granulation tissue. Skin flaps with a muscle are also used for closure.

questions.text: An 11-month-old baby boy has an empty scrotum on the right side with normal left testis. But a mass was palpable on the right inguinal canal. Ultrasonography revealed the right testicle under the subcutaneous fat near the right inguinal canal with a normal left testis. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of cryptorchidism and the next best step is to perform an orchidopexy.

Orchidopexy is the treatment of choice for incompletely palpable unilateral undescended testis. Orchidopexy is usually performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age to avoid the following complications remembered by the mnemonic TESTIS:

T- Torsion
E- Epididymorchitis
S- Sterility
T- Trauma (Increased risk)
I- Increased risk of inguinal hernia (Most commonly occurring complication)
S- Seminoma (Increased risk)

About 4% of boys are born with one or both testes incompletely descended. About two-thirds of these reach the scrotum during the first 3 months of life, but full descent after that is uncommon.

Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac.  It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The testes can arrest anywhere during descent, and the most common site is the inguinal region.

Phases of testicular descent:

  • Transabdominal phase: Testes come to lie in the lower abdomen or pelvis, and this descent is regulated by Mullerian-inhibiting substances.
  • Inguinoscrotal phase: Testes descend along the inguinal canal and reach the scrotal sac, and this phase of the descent is regulated by androgen-induced calcitonin gene-related peptide from the genitofemoral nerve.

The exact pathogenesis remains unknown; however, deficiency in gonadotropins and Mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) and increased expression of estradiol in the placenta are thought to play a role. 

Cryptorchidism is histopathologically characterized by the following: 

  1. Testicular atrophy: thickening of the basement membrane, arrested germ cell development, marked hyalinization
  2. Tubules showing Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis
  3. Increase in the interstitial Leydig cells 
Other options:

Option A: Cryptorchidism is associated with testicular atrophy and dysfunction, which result in sterility. Cryptorchid testes carry a 3–5-fold higher risk for testicular cancer (usually seminoma). Thus, observation is never the policy.
 
Option B: When the testis is not palpable, ultrasound may be helpful in identifying the intracanalicular testis, while laparoscopy may be needed to differentiate between the abdominal testis and a truly absent testis. Since here testis is made out in the inguinal region, laparoscopy is not the next best line of management.
 
Option D: Orchidectomy should be considered if the incompletely descended testis is atrophic, particularly in the postpubertal boy if the other testis is normal.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy presents to you following the burn injury as shown in the below image. Your senior consultant advises you to prescribe a topical antimicrobial that can penetrate eschar. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?
questions.solution:
The above image shows burns with eschar and among the above-mentioned topical antimicrobials, Mafenide acetate can penetrate eschar.

Mafenide acetate:

  • Mafenide acetate either in cream or solution form is an effective topical antimicrobial.
  • It is effective even in the presence of eschar as it can penetrate burn eschar to reach the interface with the patient's viable tissue.
  • It is an excellent antimicrobial for fresh skin grafts.
  • It is particularly useful against resistant Pseudomonas and Enterococcus species.
  • It has the disadvantage of being painful on topical application.
  • It is also a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and can result in metabolic acidosis when it is applied over large surfaces.

Other options:

Silver sulphadiazine: It is a most commonly used agent having a wide range of antimicrobial activity because it's silver and sulfa moieties cover gram-positive, most gram-negative, and even some fungal forms. In a few patients, transient leukopenia develops 3 to 5 days after its continued use. This leukopenia is generally harmless and resolves with or without treatment cessation.

Neomycin: Painless but the antimicrobial spectrum is not as wide as the above agents.

Silver nitrate: Effective against Pseudomonas colonization. It has the advantage of being painless on application. However prolonged topical application leads to electrolyte extravasation with resulting hyponatremia. It also causes staining of all the furniture surrounding the patient.It may cause methemoglobinemia in a few.

questions.text: A 53-year-old female patient presents with complaints of weakness for the last 2 months. Additionally, she is facing difficulty rising from a chair, and combing her hair every morning. A physical exam reveals decreased strength in the shoulders and hip. Skin findings are as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical vignette, this patient's symptoms along with the image findings showing heliotrope rash are highly suggestive of dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis involves CD 4+ cells, perimyseal infiltrates, and is associated with underlying malignancy. 

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations. The pattern of muscle involvement helps distinguish a myopathy from a cerebral, spinal cord, neuronal or neuromuscular junction cause. It is commonly associated with an underlying malignancy.

Classic signs-

  • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids
  • V sign- Confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
  • Shawl sign- Confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
  • Gottron’s papules- Erythematous papules and plaques over extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints
  • Gottron's sign- Erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles. 
  • Mechanic’s hands- Rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Facial rash- Confluent erythema in the malar distribution involving the cheeks, nasal bridge, and nasolabial folds
  • Nail fold changes
  • Flagellate erythema- Linear erythema on the upper back with pruritus
  • Poikiloderma- Mottled pattern of hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules with telangiectasias
  • Cutaneous calcinosis- Accumulation of calcium deposits in the skin.

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies. Electromyography will reveal features of myopathy. Histology will show perifascicular atrophy and immunohistochemical staining will reveal myxovirus resistance protein A, a sensitive and specific marker. 

Treatment of dermatomyositis is immunotherapy with high-dose glucocorticoids being the first line. Methotrexate can be started as the second line if the patient presents with severe weakness, other organ system involvement, or those with risk of steroid complications like patients with diabetes, osteoporosis, or postmenopausal women. Otherwise, second-line agents are only started in patients who do not show improvement after 2-4 months of treatment with prednisone or those who cannot be maintained on a low dose. Triple therapy with intravenous immunoglobulin or rituximab may be required. 

Note: Inclusion Body myositis is resistant to immunosuppressive medication

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient had acute appendicitis 3 days ago and presented to the surgery department with abdominal pain and tenderness. Which of the following incision would be appropriate for this condition?
questions.solution:
McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision), marked 3 in the image, is popularly used for open appendicectomy. It is an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. 

The major anterior abdominal incisions have been illustrated below:

  • 1 is Kocher incision - A subcostal incision used to gain access for gall bladder and/or biliary tree pathology.
  • 2 is midline incision - The most common incision for laparotomy. This vertical incision follows the linea alba which is particularly favored in diagnostic laparotomy, as they allow wide access to most of the abdominal cavity.
  • 3 is McBurney's incision (also called gridiron incision) is an oblique incision (superolateral to inferomedial) passing along McBurney's point. It is popularly used for open appendicectomy.
  • 4 is a battle incision a lower right paramedian incision but placed more laterally than the standard paramedian incision. It is suitable for dealing with acute appendicitis and pathologies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.
  • 5 is Lanz incision, a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid-inguinal line. Due to its continuation with Langer’s lines, the Lanz incision produces much more aesthetically pleasing results with reduced scarring.
  • 6 is a paramedian incision - this incision is used to access much of the lateral viscera, such as the kidneys, spleen, and adrenal glands.
  • 7 is transverse incision - A supraumbilical transverse incision offers excellent exposure to the upper abdomen. A transverse incision may be superior to a midline incision in terms of recovery and complications postoperatively.
  • 8 is Rutherford Morrison incision, an oblique muscle cutting incision used for access to the sigmoid colon and pelvis in patients where the midline is scarred due to previous surgery. Rutherford Morison’s incision is useful if the appendix is para- or retrocaecal and fixed. It is essentially an oblique muscle-cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary
  • 9 is Pfannenstiel incision - An infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: A person presents with the deformity shown in the picture and is unable to move the thumb away from the rest of the hand. Which of the following nerve is injured?
questions.solution:
The above picture shows ape thumb deformity. It results from median nerve palsy. Ape thumb deformity is inability to abduct the thumb due to paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle. The thumb remains parallel by the side of other fingers.

In the hand, the median nerve supplies muscles of the thenar eminence, mainly abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis and flexor pollicis brevis.

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes to you in her second stage of labor. On per vaginal examination, frontal sutures, anterior fontanelle, and supraorbital ridges are palpated. What could the fetal presentation be?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the fetus could be in the brow presentation.

On per vaginal examination, the palpation of frontal sutures, anterior fontanelle, and supraorbital ridges indicate that the fetus is in the brow presentation. However, neither the mouth nor the chin can be palpated on per vaginal examination.

This is a rare presentation that is diagnosed when the portion of the fetal head between the orbital ridge and the anterior fontanel presents at the pelvic inlet.

The etiology of brow presentation includes:

  • Maternal: Multiparity with pendulous abdomen, lateral obliquity of the uterus, contracted pelvis.
  • Fetal: Congenital malformations with the most common being anencephaly, congenital goiter, dolichocephalic head

The brow presentation is commonly unstable and frequently converts to a face or occipital presentation. Management is easy in the case of a small fetus and a large maternal pelvis. However, in the case of a large fetus, delivery by cesarean section is usually indicated.

Other options:

Option A: Face presentation occurs when the neck is hyper-extended and the chin is the presenting part. The facial features may be palpable on per-vaginal examination. 

Option B: Vertex presentation occurs when the neck is well flexed. A quadrangular area of the fetal skull bound by the bregma, parietal eminence, and lambdoid sutures is palpable on per-vaginal examination.

Option D: Shoulder presentation can occur when the fetus is in the transverse lie. On per vaginal examination during labor, the shoulder is identified by palpating the following parts—the acromion process, the scapula, the clavicle, and the axilla. The characteristic landmarks are
the feeling of the ribs and intercostal spaces (gridiron feel). On occasion, the arm is found prolapsed.

questions.text: Causes of acute pancreatitis are all except______
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia causes acute pancreatitis but acute pancreatitis leads to Hypocalcemia.

Acute pancreatitis:

Abdominal pain  is the major symptom of acute pancreatitis.The pain, which is steady and boring in character,is located in the epigastrium and periumbilical region.Pain may radiate to the back, chest, flanks, and lower abdomen.

In necrotizing pancreatitis, there is bruising of skin seen as

  • A-Grey turner's sign: Bruising in the flanks
  • B-Cullen's sign: Periumbilical bruising

Lab findings of acute pancreatitis include:

  • Elevated pancreatic amylase
  • Leucocytosis
  • Hyperglycemia
    • Including decreased insulin
    • Increased glucagon release
    • Output of adrenal glucocorticoids
  • Hypocalcemia (<8)
  • Hyperbilirubinemia (>4 mg / dL)
  • LDH (<8.5 micromol per litre)
  • Serum albumin (<3 g / dL)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Proteinuria
  • Granular cast

Differential diagnosis of acute pancreatitis

  • Biliary colic
  • Acute cholecystitis
  • Perforated hollow viscus (e.g., perforated peptic ulcer)
  • Mesenteric ischemia or infarction
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Dissecting aortic aneurysm
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • DKA
  • Connective tissue disorders with vasculitis

Related Pearl: Causes of Acute Pancreatitis

Common Causes

  • Gallstones (M/C cause)
  • Alcohol
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • ERCP
  • Drugs(corticosteroids, azathioprine, asparaginase, valproic acid, thiazides, oestrogens)
  • Trauma (especially blunt abdominal trauma)
  • Postoperative (abdominal and nonabdominal operations)

Uncommon Causes

  • Vascular causes and vasculitis
  • Connective tissue disorders & TTP
  • Pancreatic cancer
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Periampullary diverticulum
  • Pancreas divisum
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Renal failure
  • Infections (mumps, coxsackievirus, cytomegalovirus, echovirus, parasites)
  • Autoimmune (e.g., type 1 and type 2)

Related Pearl: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

  • At the time of admission:
    • Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP)
      • Pleural effusion
      • Presence of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
      • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL
      • Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15
      • Age > 60 years
    • Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS)
      • Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding
      • Normal haematocrit
      • Normal serum creatinine
      • If all 3 features are present then patient is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need of ventilation
  • 24-hours following admission:
    • Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II) score of 8 or more
    • Can also be done at admission and repeated any time
    • Disadvantages: Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age, which easily upgrades the acute pancreatitis severity score
  • At 48 hours of admission:
    • Serum C-reactive protein level of >150 mg/dL
    • Ranson’s score
    • Modified Glasgow criteria
    • In above 2 scores when there are 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered “predicted severe.”

Related Pearl: Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Acute Pancreatitis

Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Non-gallstone pancreatitis:

At presentation

  • Age >55 years
  • Blood glucose level, >200 mg/dL
  • White blood cell count, >16,000 cells/mm3
  • Serum lactate dehydrogenase level, >350 IU/L
  • Serum Aspartate aminotransferase level >250 IU/L

After 48 hours of admission

  • Hematocrit: decrease >10%
  • Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL
  • Base deficit >4 mEq/L
  • Blood urea nitrogen level: increase >5 mg/dL
  • Fluid requirement >6 L
  • PaO2 <60 mm Hg

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Gallstone Pancreatitis:

At presentation

  • Age >70 years
  • Blood glucose level, >220 mg/dL
  • White blood cell count, >18,000 cells/mm3
  • Serum lactate dehydrogenase level, >400 IU/L
  • Serum aspartate aminotransferase level, >250 IU/L

After 48 hours of admission

  • Hematocrit: decrease >10%
  • Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL
  • Base deficit >5 mEq/L
  • Blood urea nitrogen level: increase >2 mg/dL
  • Fluid requirement >4 L
  • PaO2: Not available

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

questions.text: Lung malignancy is most commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
Asbestosis is most commonly associated with Mesotheliomas,  pleural malignancy. 

Asbestos-related diseases include:

  • Localized fibrous plaques or diffuse pleural fibrosis
  • Pleural effusion
  • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Mesotheliomas
  • Laryngeal, ovarian and colon carcinomas

Asbestosis:

  • Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis that occurs after 5-10 years of exposure to asbestos. However, once established, it progresses even in the further removal of the worker from its contact. Asbestosis affects the basal part of the lung causing diffuse peribronchial fibrosis.
  • Asbestos is of 2 types i.e Serpentine/Chrysolite variety and Amphibole type
  • Amphibole type has the following varieties:
    • Crocidolite(blue)
    • Amosite(brown)
    • Anthrophyllite(white)
  • Sputum shows asbestos body, which are asbestos fibres coated with fibrin.
  • They present with cough and exertional dyspnoea and predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes.
  • Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.
  • X-ray shows peripheral reticular opacities predominantly in the lower zones. HRCT shows subpleural fibrotic lines, irregular opacities, traction bronchiectasis and honeycombing. Lung parenchymal involvement occurs after years of exposure (at least 10 years).
  • The complications that can occur are
    • Pulmonary fibrosis 
    • Carcinoma of the lung 
    • Malignancy of the Gastrointestinal tract
    • Mesothelioma of the pleura

Preventive measures:

  • Using a safer type of Asbestos (chrysolite and amosite)
  • Substituting other insulants like glass fibre, mineral wool, calcium silicate, plastic foams etc
  • Dust control
  • Periodic examination of workers
  • Continuing research

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for breast conservative surgery?

choices.text: Tumor size < 4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis
Tumor more than the size of the breast

questions.solution:
