questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with hepatitis and personality changes. A picture of her eye has been provided below. Which of the following is the drug of choice for pregnant women and maintenance therapy for this condition?
questions.solution:
The image provided above represents the Kayser-Fleischer ring which is seen in Wilson's disease. The drug of choice for maintenance therapy in this condition is Zinc.

Wilsons disease is an autosomal-recessive disease caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea. It is characteristically observed in Wilson's disease but is not pathognomic. It does not interfere with vision. It is present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms. However, the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Neurological: Dystonia, rigidity, tremor or choreiform movements, abnormal gait due to basal ganglia (e.g., caudate, putamen) involvement.
  • Behavioural disturbancesOccular characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Diagnosis:

    • Sternlieb's criteria: Presence of KF rings
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
    • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy
    • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

The initial treatment in symptomatic patients is the administration of copper-chelating agents, which leads to the rapid excretion of excess deposited copper.

  • D-penicillamine: It increases urinary excretion of copper and prevents copper overload. Pyridoxine (vitamin B6 ) is administered along with it to counter pyridoxine deficiency that occurs due to penicillamine.
  • Triethylenetetramine dihydrochloride: This chelating agent is given in patients intolerant to D-penicillamine and those with severe neurologic manifestations (D-penicillamine worsens neurological status).
  • Zinc acetate: This is used due to its unique ability to impair the gastrointestinal absorption of copper. Zinc is beneficial in pregnancy (lower teratogenic effects) and as a maintenance therapy.
  • Liver transplantation: This is considered in advanced stages of irreversible hepatic damage or poor compliance to medical therapy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, a known case of  COPD was admitted to the ICU and was on oxygen therapy with 2 Liters of oxygen. He was found to be hypo-ventilating and an arterial blood gas analysis done showed pH:7.33 and pCO2 as 64 mmHg. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Since the patient is having an acute exacerbation of COPD and his ABG shows PaCO2 >45 mmHg and pH<7.35, he is having acidosis and respiratory failure. This is an indication for Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation and is the next step in the management of this patient.

Initial management of acute exacerbation of COPD includes:

  • Bronchodilators: Inhaled beta-agonists and muscarinic antagonists
  • Antibiotics
  • Supplemental oxygen

If initial NIPPV fails, then, invasive PPV may be provided. However, during the invasive PPV, the tidal volume is reduced to prevent damage to the alveolar structures. Contraindications of NIPPV:

  • Cardiovascular instability
  • Impaired mental status or inability to cooperate
  • Copious secretions or the inability to clear secretions
  • Craniofacial abnormalities
  • Trauma precluding effective fitting of the mask
  • Extreme obesity

There are two methods used for the creation of a pneumoperitoneum:

questions.text: Which of the following  is not a cardinal movement occurring during labor?

questions.solution:

Hanging mark

  • The hanging mark almost never completely encircles the neck unless a slipknot is used.
  • In most instances the point of suspension is indicated by a gap in the skin mark.
  • This gap is usually seen at one or other side of the neck or at the centre of the back of the neck. Much less often it is under the chin.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman at 33 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of excessive fatigue and palpitations. On examination, severe pallor and pedal edema are present with an oxygen saturation of 89%. Her hemoglobin is 5.9 g/dL. Which among the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best treatment option for this patient is packed cell transfusion.

The treatment of choice for anemia with hemoglobin between 5-7 g/dL at < 34 weeks period of gestation with hypoxia and an impending sign of heart failure like pedal edema is packed cell transfusion. Only packed cell transfusions are carried out and about 80 mL-100 mL of blood is infused at a time and repeated only after 24 hours. 

The following precautions are taken prior to blood transfusions:

  • Administration of antihistaminics intramuscularly
  • Administration of diuretics intramuscularly at least 2 hours prior to transfusion to produce negative fluid balance
  • Adjustment of the drip rate to 10 drops/minute
  • Observation of the pulse, respiration, and basal lung crepitations. 

The complications of blood transfusions include premature labor, increased chances of worsening cardiac failure, and transfusion reactions.

Following are the RCOG guidelines for initiating blood transfusion during pregnancy:

  • Antepartum period
    1. Pregnancy < 34 weeks:
      1. Hb <5 g/dL with or without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
      2. Hb 5-7 g/dL – in presence of impending heart failure
    2. Pregnancy > 34 weeks:
      1. Hb <7 g/dL even without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
      2. Severe anemia with decompensation
    3. Anemia not due to hematinic deficiency:
      1. Hemoglobinopathy or bone marrow failure syndromes
      2. Consult hematologist
    4. Acute hemorrhage:
      1. Always indicated if Hb <6 g/dL
      2. If the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable due to ongoing hemorrhage
  • Intrapartum period
    1. Hb <7 g/dL 
    2. The decision of blood transfusion depends on medical history or symptoms
  • Postpartum period
    1. Hb <7g%
    2. Anemia with signs of shock/acute hemorrhage with signs of hemodynamic instability.

Other options given are parenteral formulations of iron therapy that are not indicated according to the criteria given above. Parenteral iron therapy is indicated in the following conditions:

  •  Contraindications of oral therapy such as severe gastrointestinal side effects of taking oral iron (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, teeth staining, epigastric distress)
  •  Non-cooperative patient 
  •  Cases that are seen for the first time during the last 8–10 weeks with severe anemia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male is brought to the ER with complaints of nausea, muscle weakness, and a sense of extreme fatigue. History is significant for a diagnosis of chronic kidney disease and treatment with enalapril for the same. His ECG is given below. What is the first step in management?
questions.solution:
The history points to hyperkalemia as a potential diagnosis, while absent P waves and peaked T waves on the ECG indicate cardiac toxicity of potassium. The ECG findings constitute a medical emergency and immediate intravenous infusion of calcium gluconate is the first step in management.

ECG changes seen in association with varying levels of hyperkalemia (Normal Serum K+ 3.5-4.5 mEq/L) -

  • 5.5-6.5 mEq/L - Tall peaked T waves, short QT interval, ST-segment depression
  • 6.5-8.0 mEq/L - Peaked T waves, prolonged PR interval, disappearing P waves, QRS widening
  • >8.0 mEq/L - Absent P waves, progressive QRS widening, fascicular/ bundle branch blocks

Management of hyperkalemia:

1) Cardiac stabilization:

With cardiac monitoring, IV infusion of 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate in 2-3 minutes reverses the cardiac depolarization blockade caused by hyperkalemia. This serves to prevent fatal arrhythmias such as sinus bradycardia/arrest, asystole, and ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation.

2) Displacement of potassium into cells:

The next step involves the administration of 10 units of intravenous regular insulin with/without iv dextrose (50 mL of 50% dextrose) based on monitored glucose concentrations. This serves to shift the potassium into the cells. Inhaled beta-2 agonists have an additive effect and can be used along with insulin.

IV bicarbonate is especially helpful with sustained administration over hours and if metabolic acidosis is associated with hyperkalemia.

3) Definitive removal of potassium from the body:

It is accomplished by using cation exchange resins, diuretics, and through dialysis.

A peaked T wave is the first ECG change in hyperkalemia, and with increasing potassium concentration, P waves are lost and QRS complexes widen, ultimately deteriorating into ventricular arrhythmias/asystole.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension?
questions.solution:
Liddle's syndrome is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension.

It is an autosomal dominant condition due to a gain of function mutation in the ENaC gene. This gene codes for the epithelial sodium channels present in the kidney. This leads to increased sodium retention and results in a state of pseudo-hyperaldosteronism. The following findings are seen:

  • Hypertension
  • Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis
  • Normal-low aldosterone
  • Low renin 

Treatment is with diuretics that directly block the ENaC channels, like amiloride and triamterene. Spironolactone is not effective as it is an aldosterone-receptor antagonist.

Other options:

Option A- Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to defects in various genes involved in the regulated Na+, K+, and Cl– transport by the thick ascending loop of Henle (TALH). There is extracellular fluid volume depletion with low or normal blood pressure. It is characterized by metabolic alkalosis, decreased potassium and chloride, and, occasionally, hypomagnesemia. 

Option C- Gitelman syndrome is due to a loss of function mutation in the thiazide-sensitive Na+-Cl– cotransporter of the distal convoluted tubule. It is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypomagnesemia and hypocalciuria with low blood pressure.

Option D- Gordon syndrome is a state of pseudohypoaldosteronism. It is characterized by hypertension, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and low-normal plasma renin activity and aldosterone concentrations.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G3P2 was admitted to the labor room at 34 weeks of gestation in view of  BP - 150/90mmHg and Urine albumin - 2+. Which of the following drugs is not used to control BP in this patient ______
questions.solution:
Captopril is an ACE inhibitor and it is contraindicated in pregnancy.

High BP and proteinuria are diagnostic of pre-eclampsia. Methyl dopa, labetalol, and hydralazine are agents used for the management of pre-eclampsia.

ACE Inhibitor effects on the fetus: These drugs inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to the potent vasoconstrictor angiotensin-II. They can cause severe fetal malformations when given in the second and third trimesters.

Anti-hypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy:

  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers 
  • Diuretics (Contraindicated as an anti-hypertensive but can be given in CCF)
  • Reserpine
  • Sodium Nitroprusside (used only as a drug of last resort in refractory severe hypertension)
  • Diazoxide

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals the following finding. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. What is the most common cause of this condition in such patients?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with a positive Kernig's sign, is suggestive of meningitis. Cryptococcus is the leading infectious cause of meningitis in patients with AIDS. It generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL.            

Most patients present with a picture of subacute meningoencephalitis. The CSF profile may show modest elevations in WBC or protein levels and decrease in glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated (yeast colonies obstruct the free flow of CSF causing increased CSF pressure).

The diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made by identification of Cryptococcus neoformans yeast cells in CSF with india ink stain or by the detection of cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination (CrAg).

Prophylaxis: Oral fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/μL.

Treatment:

  • Induction - IV or liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, continuing with amphotericin alone ideally until the CSF culture turns negative.
  • Maintenance -  Oral fluconazole until the CD4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/μL for 6 months in response to cART.

questions.text: Which type of non-union does the given radiograph signify?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows hypertrophic nonunion of the tibia.

Although the enlarged fracture ends suggest active osteogenesis, the gap is not bridged because of inadequate stability. Such non-unions have adequate vascularity and display abundant callus.

Based on increasing biologic potential for fracture healing, non-union can be of the following types:

  • Atrophic nonunion
  • Oligotrophic nonunion
  • Hypertrophic nonunion

Pseudoarthrosis has features of hypertrophic nonunion, but due to excessive and chronic motility, there is the formation of a pseudo-capsule containing fluid similar to an actual synovial joint.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrect?

choices.text: Rosenbach sign - Pulsations of the liver
Traube's sign - Pulsations of the spleen
Muller's sign - Systolic pulsations of uvula

questions.solution:
The incorrect pair is Traube's sign - Pulsations of the spleen. Traube's sign is a pistol shot sound heard over femoral arteries seen in aortic regurgitation (AR).

Aortic regurgitation (AR) is a valvular disease of the aortic valve caused by primary valve disease, aortic root disease or their combination.

Auscultatory findings in AR are:

  • Soft S1 - due to the early closure of the mitral valve
  • Diminished or absent A2
  • S3 - due to increased left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic volume. The presence of S3 may be a sign of impaired LV function.
  • Early diastolic murmur -
    • High-pitched, blowing, decrescendo, early diastolic murmur
    • Best heard in the left-third intercostal space
    • Heard with the patient sitting up and leaning forward, with breath held in forced expiration
    • Duration of the murmur best correlates with the severity
  • Systolic ejection murmur - It is heard due to increased LV stroke volume and ejection rate.
  • Austin Flint murmur - a low-pitched, mid to late diastolic murmur. It is caused due to the large volume of regurgitant blood, hitting the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve or LV wall.

Other signs :

  • Gerhardt’s sign- Pulsations of the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly (Option B)
  • Rosenbach sign- pulsations are felt over the liver (Option A)
  • Becker's sign is the presence of retinal artery pulsation on fundoscopy (Option C)
  • Muller's sign- systolic pulsations of the uvula (Option D)

Treatment of aortic regurgitation:

In non-severe AR, periodic monitoring can be done. Diuretics and vasodilators can manage the symptoms of dyspnea and decreased cardiac output.

In severe AR, surgery is indicated in the following conditions:

  • The patient is symptomatic
  • The patient is asymptomatic, but the LV ejection fraction is less than 50% or LV end-diastolic diameter is more than 65mm.
  • The patient is asymptomatic and undergoing other cardiac surgeries.

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a 23-year-old man presents with breathlessness. On examination, he has hypotension and distended neck veins. On auscultation, muffled heart sounds are heard. What is this condition primarily associated with?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of Beck's triad (hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds) is seen in cardiac tamponade. Shock due to cardiac tamponade is primarily an example of obstructive shock.

Obstructive shock is characterized by a reduction in preload due to mechanical obstruction of the cardiac filling of the left and/or right sides of the heart, which in turn leads to fall in cardiac output. Common causes of obstructive shock include:

  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Massive pulmonary embolus or air embolus

Cardiogenic shock is due to primary failure of the heart to pump blood. It may be due to myocardial depression as a result of infarction, cardiomyopathy, blunt myocardial injury. Patients with cardiac tamponade may eventually develop cardiogenic shock as the myocardium is stressed against the obstruction.

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for erectile dysfunction. Which of the following will help differentiate a psychological cause from an organic one?

choices.text: Decreased vibratory perception in the penis
Absence of erection with any partner

questions.solution:
The presence of nocturnal penile tumescence almost rules out organic causes of erectile dysfunction.

Organic causes are considered negligible in the following:

  • Spontaneous erections at times when he does not plan to have intercourse.
  • Having morning erections or nocturnal penile tumescence (erection during REM sleep).
  • Only sporadic erectile dysfunction.
  • Having good erections with masturbation.
  • Having a good erection with partners other than his usual one.

Organic (non-psychogenic) causes of erectile dysfunction:

  • Vasculogenic - arterial insufficiency, venous leak
  • Endocrinologic - hypogonadism, hyperprolactinemia
  • Neurogenic
  • Iatrogenic

questions.text: A  5 year old child presented to your OPD genu varum.  X-ray showed osteopenia and pseudofractures. Investigations show decreased vitamin D and increased ALP. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the investigations in this child are suggestive of rickets caused by vitamin D deficiency, a disease which is similar to osteomalacia.

Metabolic bone disorders due to nutritional deficiencies include:

  • Vitamin D deficiency leads to:
    • Rickets- in children
    • Osteomalacia- in adults
    • Secondary hyperparathyroidism 
  • Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy

Since this question does not have the option of rickets, a disease with similar pathology is the most likely diagnosis which is osteomalacia.

Rickets occurs due to a nutritional deficiency in vitamin D. Decrease in vitamin D levels leads to decreased calcium and phosphate due to reduced absorption. The decreased calcium stimulates increased parathyroid hormone(PTH) production. ALP level is increased as it is involved in bone mineralization.

Clinical features of rickets include

  • General features such as malnourishment, abdominal distension, proximal muscle weakness, etc.
  • Head: Softening of the skull bones, called craniotabes, delayed closure of fontanels.
  • Chest: Rachitic rosary, i.e. widening of the costochondral junctions that give the feeling of rosary beads on palpation. Harrison's groove, a horizontal groove in the lower chest, may appear from the inward pull of the softened ribs by the diaphragm during respiration.
  • Vertebral column abnormalities like scoliosis, kyphosis, and lordosis 
  • In the distal extremities widening of the wrists and ankles, varus/ valgus deformities, windswept deformity (valgus on the side and varus on the contralateral side), anterior tibial bowing.

The laboratory findings in rickets show normal/decreased serum calcium, decreased phosphorous, elevated PTH, and increased ALP levels

Other options:

Option A: Osteopetrosis is a disorder involving defective bone resorption (defective osteoclasts). Patients present with macrocephaly (due to hydrocephalus), developmental delay, pancytopenia (reduced bone marrow cavity), and hepatosplenomegaly (compensatory extramedullary hematopoiesis). Blood investigations show low serum calcium and phosphorus levels with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) and normal vitamin D levels. X-ray findings include diffuse bone sclerosis with clubbing of metaphyses. Bone within the bone appearance and "sandwich" appearance of the vertebral bodies can be seen.

Option C: Osteitis deformans also called Paget's disease is characterized by increased osteoclastic activity leading to increased bone turnover. The internal architecture is abnormal and the bone is unusually brittle. Lab tests show raised plasma alkaline phosphatase, normal calcium and phosphate levels. X-ray findings reveal both sclerotic and osteolytic lesions. Characteristic radiographic findings include-Brim sign(thickened iliopectineal line), flame-shaped lesions in long bones, picture-frame vertebral bodies, osteogenesis circumscripta (radiolucency due to osteoporosis in the skull).

Option D: Osteoporosis is characterized by an abnormally low bone mass/density (vs. osteomalacia - defective mineralization of bone due to vitamin-D deficiency). Patients present with chronic back pain or pathological fractures commonly involving the distal part of the radius (Colle's fracture), hip and vertebrae. Laboratory examination reveals normal calcium and alkaline phosphatase levels. Radiographic findings include loss of trabecular definition, thinning of the cortices, fractures and wedging of the vertebra due to compression of vertebral bodies.

Related Pearl: Radiological features of rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: Among the following, which isotope is used in nuclear scanning?
questions.solution:
Technetium agents based on technetium-99m (Tc-99m) radioisotope are the most frequently used agents in nuclear imaging.

The radioactive technetium can be chelated to a number of different compounds to create specific radiopharmaceuticals and optimize imaging of various structures. The half-life of Tc 99m is 6 hours. It produces gamma rays of 140 keV.

Iodine 125 (I 125), caesium 137 (Cs 137), and iridium 192 (Ir 192) are used in radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the OPD with mild fever since 12 days, non-productive cough, headache, and neck rigidity. The patient also complained of multiple joint pains. A chest x-ray was done which shows interstitial infiltration. Which is the most likely causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of mild fever, insidious onset and non-productive cough along with extrapulmonary manifestations i.e neck rigidity(aseptic meningitis) and joint pains are highly suggestive of mycoplasma (Walking Pneumonia). On chest X-ray interstitial infiltration along with patchy consolidation at hilum and fanning to the periphery is seen (as shown above)

Mycoplasma is the most common bacteria causing atypical pneumonia and the second most common cause of pneumonia. Clinically it has an insidious onset, non-productive cough, and milder fever compared to typical pneumonia.   Only 10% of patients present with pneumonia. URTI (tracheobronchitis/ pharyngitis) is a common pulmonary manifestation.

It is often associated with extrapulmonary manifestations. Extrapulmonary manifestations include neurologic manifestations like encephalitis or aseptic meningitis (as seen in this patient), cold agglutinin disease (IgM mediated AIHA), Erythema multiforme or SJS, arthralgia with adenopathy, Guillain barre syndrome, myocarditis, pericarditis, encephalitis, and bullous myringitis.  Investigations include PCR of respiratory secretions and chest X-rays.

Azithromycin is the drug of choice for management. Doxycycline is the second-best drug for the management of atypical pneumonia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with numerous itchy skin lesions on his chest and back which show characteristic collarette scales. 2 weeks prior to this he had noticed a round, scaly, erythematous lesion as shown in the image given below, on his thigh. Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: More common in children and young adults
Associated with viruses like HHV- 6 and HHV-7
Topical steroids can be used to relieve pruritus

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with the image showing a herald patch, is suggestive of pityriasis rosea. It is an acute self-limiting condition, with very low recurrence rates. 

Pityriasis rosea/pityriasis circinata is an acute self-limiting papulosquamous disorder. It is commonly seen in children and young adults.

Even though the exact cause is unknown, T-cell mediated immunity and infectious etiology are thought to be responsible for this condition. An association with infectious agents like human herpesvirus-6 (HHV-6) and human herpesvirus-7 (HHV-7) has been found recently.

Clinical features include:

  • Prodrome of a sore throat, gastrointestinal disturbance, fever or arthralgia.
  • Herald patch - Large and conspicuous eruptions on the thigh, upper arm, trunk or neck covered by fine scales

The image given below shows a herald patch.

  • After 5-15 days, it turns into discrete oval lesions, dull pink in color and covered by fine dry silvery-grey scales. 
  • These secondary lesions occur as macules and papules that are elliptical or ovular, symmetric, and commonly involve the thorax, back, and abdomen.
  • It is followed by a marginal collarette of scale with a central wrinkling and atrophy. The collarettes of the scales are attached peripherally. It is also called a hanging curtain sign.

The image given below shows collarette scales.

  • The long axes of the lesions characteristically follow the lines of skin tension parallel to the ribs in a Christmas tree pattern on the upper chest and back.

 The images given below show a Christmas tree pattern along the lines of skin tension on the back and the chest.

The rashes of pityriasis rosea usually resolve by 8 weeks.

Dermatoscopy shows:

  • Yellowish background-color
  • Peripheral arrangement of the scales
  • Patchy distribution of loosely arranged dotted vessels

Histopathology shows:

  • Superficial perivascular dermatitis with focal parakeratosis, hyperplasia and spongiosis in the epidermis.
  • Extravasated red blood cells along with a perivascular infiltrate and subcorneal pustules are seen in the dermis

No treatment is required for asymptomatic cases. Application of irritants to the skin and tanning should be avoided, since it may result in pigmentary changes. Emollients and antihistaminics are useful to relieve the itching. If symptomatic, various agents are used like:

  • First-line agents: If severe pruritus or poor cosmetic appeal is present
    • Topical steroids
    • Narrowband UV-B therapy
  • Second-line agents: For a rapid resolution of the lesions, in view of the probable infectious aetiology.
    • Antivirals like acyclovir
    • Macrolides like erythromycin

Pityriasis rosea within the first few weeks of gestation may cause premature delivery and fetal demise. Pityriasis rosea-like eruptions were reported after ingestion of drugs like gold, captopril, aspirin, metronidazole and clonidine and after vaccinations like BCG, influenza, diphtheria, hepatitis B, and Pneumococcus.

questions.text: A middle aged female patient comes to the OPD with a history of a lump in the left breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump is 9×10 cm with the following appearance and no axillary lymphadenopathy. The histopathology of the biopsy from the lump shows increased stromal cellularity and typical leaflike architecture. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image is suggestive of cystosarcoma phyllodes/Phyllodes tumor of the breast.

Phyllodes tumor, also known as cystosarcoma phyllodes, presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin though the overlying skin becomes thin and tense due to swelling. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition.

The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of a phyllodes tumor. Axillary dissection is not done if malignant transformation occurs because the lymphatic spread is rare.

Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcoma phyllodes or serocystic disease of Brodie. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. Histologically, there is a wide variation with some having low malignant potential and others having a higher mitotic index.

Treatment of phyllodes tumor:

  • Benign type- Enucleation or wide local excision
  • Massive tumors, recurrent tumors, and malignant type- Mastectomy

The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of a phyllodes tumor.

 

Other options:

Option B: Giant fibroadenomas are usually seen in the early reproductive years. These are benign solid encapsulated tumors. It is a slow-growing tumor and presents as a painless lump in the breast.

Option C and D: Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The pathologic hallmark of inflammatory cancer is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics. Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases.

Patients with inflammatory carcinoma usually have a history revealing the rapid onset of the disease with progression over weeks to 3 months.

The hallmark of inflammatory breast cancer is diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatic channels within the breast and overlying skin, often without an underlying tumor mass. Inflammatory breast cancer manifests clinically as erythema, edema, and warmth of the breast as a result of lymphatic obstruction.

questions.text: The most common acute complication of hemodialysis is _______.
questions.solution:
Hypotension is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis, particularly among patients with diabetes mellitus.

Acetate, a buffer in the dialysate is the most common cause of dialysis-induced hypotension because of its vasodilatory and cardio-depressive effects. Dialysis-associated hypotension has become less common these days due to the use of bicarbonate.

Acute complications of Hemodialysis :

  • The most common is hypotension, particularly among patients with diabetes mellitus.
  • Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome
  • Anaphylaxis
  • High output cardiac failure if AV fistula or graft is used for access.
  • Muscle cramps.

questions.text: An intern observed that a patient in the ward was unresponsive, and an ECG which was performed urgently showed a rhythm as depicted below. DC shock was delivered but the arrhythmia persisted and the patient is still unresponsive. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is in cardiac arrest and the rhythm shown is that of ventricular fibrillation. Since DC shock was given and the patient is still unresponsive, CPR has to be given for 2 minutes after which the rhythm should be assessed again. 

The management of ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia is the same. Chest compressions are to be started following defibrillation.

Defibrillation involves delivering an electrical current between two pads placed on the chest so as to interrupt the disorganized cardiac activity and restore an organized cardiac rhythm. The energy that must be applied is

  • Monophasic defibrillator: 360 J
  • Biphasic defibrillator: 120-200 J

It is of utmost necessity to defibrillate at the earliest because the chances of survival decrease by 7-10% every minute without defibrillation.

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she developed dialysis disequilibrium syndrome. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The treatment for this patients with dialysis disequilibrium syndrome (DDS) or the reverse urea effect is IV mannitol 

It is an acute complication that occurs especially in patients undergoing dialysis for the first time.

During dialysis, urea in blood vessels is rapidly removed as compared to that in the interstitium. This decreases the osmolality of blood. This results in a fluid shift from the blood vessels into the interstitium and brain parenchyma, causing cerebral edema.

DDS can present as headache, nausea, blurred vision, restlessness, confusion, and severe manifestations like coma and seizures in rare cases.

The most common risk factors include

  • First hemodialysis treatment
  • High blood urea nitrogen (BUN) (above 175 mg/dL or 60 mmol/L) before initiation of dialysis
  • Children and elderly
  • Sudden change in dialysis regimen
  • Hyponatremia, hepatic encephalopathy
  • Sepsis, meningitis, encephalitis, hemolytic uremic syndrome, vasculitis
  • History of stroke, malignant hypertension, head trauma, or seizure disorder

Management includes changing the sodium dialysate bath or engaging the changed prescription on the dialysis machine. Intravenous mannitol can be used to reduce intracerebral pressure in severe symptoms of DDS.

DDS can be prevented by 

  • Slow and gentle initial hemodialysis
  • Limiting the clearance of urea to prevent the development of an osmotic gradient
  • Administration of osmotically active substance

questions.text: A young woman with ongoing seizures and respiratory distress was rushed to the casualty by her relatives with an alleged history of attempted suicide by drug overdose. She was febrile, her heart rate was 180 bpm, BP was 70/50 mmHg. Her mouth was dry and her pupils were dilated. ABG showed a pH of 7.1, bicarbonate level was 14 mmol/L and pCO2 was 30 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning i.e metabolic acidosis, tachycardia, hypotension, and pupillary dilatation. Imipramine is a TCA. 

Tricyclic antidepressant overdose:

Clinical features:

  • CNS- seizures, respiratory depression, drowsiness, delirium. 
  • CVS - sinus tachycardia, hypotension, prolonged PR/QRS/QT interval, arrhythmias (ventricular tachycardia, fibrillation)
  • Anticholinergic - dilated pupils, dry mouth, urinary retention, hyperthermia

Treatment:

  • Oxygen supplementation and IV fluids
  • Activated charcoal if the patient is brought within two hours of ingestion (unless ileus present)
  • IV sodium bicarbonate (attenuates the TCA-induced cardiotoxicity and metabolic acidosis)

Note: Dialysis is not very helpful in the management of TCA overdose.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with sudden onset of a headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. He had several such episodes in the past. During these episodes, his BP is found to be high. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
The most likely etiology is pheochromocytoma. Patients commonly present with a classical triad of palpitation, headache and profuse sweating. The presence of this triad in association with hypertension and elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine makes pheochromocytoma a likely diagnosis.

Pheochromocytoma is one of the important endocrine causes of secondary hypertension.

Secondary causes of hypertension are:

  • Renal causes- Renal artery stenosis, renal cysts, fibromuscular dysplasia
  • Adrenal causes- Primary aldosteronism, Cushing's syndrome, pheochromocytoma
  • Other endocrine causes- Hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, acromegaly
  • Coarctation of aorta
  • Obstructive sleep apnea
  • Preeclampsia/eclampsia
  • Prolonged use of oral contraceptive pills, adrenal steroids, nasal decongestants can also cause hypertension
  • Monogenic hypertension- these conditions are due to the mutation of a single gene. Eg. Liddle's syndrome

questions.text: In a patient requiring invasive BP monitoring, which is the preferred artery used for canulation and measurement?
questions.solution:
Radial artery is the preferred artery for invasive blood pressure monitoring because of ease of cannulation, presence of collateral blood flow and less associated complications.

Before cannulating the radial artery, it is essential to perform a modified Allen’s test in order to determine the adequacy of collateral flow to the hand.

The other arteries which can be used for invasive blood pressure monitoring are ulnar, brachial, axillary, and femoral arteries and less commonly dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, and superficial temporal arteries.

questions.text: A young cricketer presented with severe pain and deformity of the shoulder following bowling practice. The AP-view radiograph of the affected shoulder is given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Bankart lesion may occur as a complication
Recurrence is associated with Hill-Sachs lesion
Radial nerve is most commonly injured
It can also be caused by a fall on the hand

questions.solution:
This radiograph shows anterior dislocation of the shoulder. The nerve commonly injured in anterior dislocation is the axillary nerve, not the radial nerve. 

The radiograph shows the disturbed articulation between the humeral head and glenoid fossa. The humeral head is seen below and medial to the glenoid socket. This suggests anterior dislocation of the shoulder joint. 

Common cause for anterior dislocation:

  • Young adults - athletic injuries
  • Elderly - falls (Option D)

Complications include:

  • Bankart lesion (Option A) is a tear in the anteroinferior part of the glenoid labrum caused by the head of the humerus during anterior dislocation. 
  • Hill-Sachs lesion is a compression fracture on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head. It is caused by the pressure of the anterior glenoid rim on the humeral head in recurrent dislocations. (Option B)

questions.text: At what point do you begin plotting on a partogram when the first contractions occur?
questions.solution:
In a partograph, labor is graphed and analysis includes use of action lines and alert lines.

A partograph was designed by WHO for use in developing countries. Partograph is similar for nulliparas and multiparas.

Active phase starts at 3cm cervical dilatation and progress should be no slower than 1cm/hour.

A 4 hour wait is recommended before intervention when the active phase is slow.

In the modified partograph, there is no plotting of the latent phase. The partograph is plotted once active labor begins.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presented to the OPD with a history of a painless mass in the neck. Fine needle aspiration cytology is reported as a follicular neoplasm. Hemithyroidectomy is performed and the frozen section is sent to the pathologist for evaluation. Which among the following features confirms the presence of follicular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Capsular or vascular invasion confirms the presence of follicular carcinoma.

Fine needle aspiration cytology cannot differentiate between the follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma. Hence, if the FNAC shows the presence of follicular neoplasm, hemithyroidectomy is performed. The frozen section of the excised specimen has to be evaluated. The presence of capsular or vascular invasion confirms the presence of follicular carcinoma.

Other features like nuclear polymorphism, atypia, and prominent nucleoli can be present in follicular adenoma.

Hurthle cell change refers to the increased eosinophilic granular cytoplasm in the neoplastic cells. It can be seen in both follicular carcinoma and adenoma.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

More common in iodine-deficient areas

Mean age of presentation is 50 years

Commonly present as solitary thyroid nodules

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions

Malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion

Associated with P53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS 

miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346) are associated with follicular carcinoma

Histology:

  • Usually solitary lesion
  • Encapsulated
  • Has uniform micro follicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumor thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere.

The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumor recurrence because this thyroid protein should be barely detectable in a patient who is free of disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with bilateral adnexal masses and ascites. Histopathological examination of the resected specimen shows sheets of mucin-producing signet-ring cells. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis with the above clinical interpretation is metastatic signet-ring carcinoma called Krukenberg tumor.

Krukenberg tumor is a metastatic ovarian malignancy with the primary site is in the gastrointestinal tract or breast. It is often bilateral. Primary sites include the stomach (70%); carcinoma of the colon, appendix, and breast (mainly invasive lobular carcinoma). Numerous signet-ring cells are seen in the Krukenberg tumor. Signet ring cells are mucin-producing cells with the appearance of a signet ring often originating from the gastric mucosa.

questions.text: A patient presents with a white lesion in his mouth which he noticed a month ago. He is a smoker. Oral examination shows a white patch that is adherent and cannot be scrapped off. Oral cavity findings are seen in the image below.  What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Considering the clinical presentation, the lesion shown in the image is suggestive of leukoplakia. The next step of management of this patient will be to do a biopsy of the lesion.

Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity. It is seen anywhere in the upper aerodigestive tract. It may represent squamous hyperplasia, dysplasia, and/or carcinoma with an associated risk of malignant transformation.

A biopsy should be done to establish a diagnosis and an appropriate work-up is done if carcinoma is identified. Severe dysplasia and carcinoma in situ are premalignant lesions and are treated with complete surgical excision. Mild and moderate dysplasia may be observed or excised.

Cessation of smoking, elimination of the areca nut/pan habit, and reduction in alcohol consumption should be encouraged in all patients with premalignant lesions.

Oral thrush is most commonly caused by Candida albicans. It is a white coating covering your mouth and throat. Scraping it off with a tongue depressor shows inflamed red areas that often bleed slightly as well. Oral thrush can be treated with topical or oral antifungals.

Oral submucosal fibrosis is characterized by the formation of fibrous bands beneath the oral cavity. The disease is progressive and causes limitation of mouth opening and restricted tongue movements. Intralesional steroids and surgical excision of fibrous bands are recommended.

questions.text: In a case of suspected homicide, the wife has been arrested for allegedly shooting the husband. She was found to be guilty based on the presence of gunpowder residue on her hands. Which of the following tests is the most sensitive for detection of gunpowder residue?

questions.solution:
Scanning Electron Microscopy with energy dispersive X-ray Analysis is the most sensitive test for detection of gunshot residue(GSRs).

Tests for detection of gunpowder residue

  • Dermal nitrate (paraffin) test
  • Harrison and Gilroy test
  • Neutron Activation Analysis (NAA)
  • Flameless Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy (FAAS)
  • Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) - a variant of Flameless Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy
  • Scanning Electron Microscopy with Energy Dispersive X-ray Analysis (SEM -EDX)

The most commonly used method for the detection of gunshot residue is scanning electron microscopy–energy-dispersive x-ray spectrometry (SEM–EDX).

questions.text: An elderly patient is brought to the emergency in a comatose state. Examination reveals serum glucose levels of 500 mg/dL, arterial pH of 7.33, elevated plasma ketones, and normal serum potassium levels. What should be added to the saline in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient has diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The patient needs to be started on IV fluids and insulin at a dose of 0.1 unit per kg. 

Diabetic ketoacidosis is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain.

Signs:

  • Kussmaul breathing
  • Fruity odor on the patient’s breath
  • Tachycardia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypotension

Blood parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia – 250 – 600 mg%
  • Pseudohyponatremia- There is 1.6-mmol/L reduction in serum sodium level for each 5.6-mmol/L rise in the serum glucose level.
  • Overall total-body K+ deficit, however, the serum K+ at presentation may be mildly elevated, secondary to the acidosis
  • Osmolality– 300–320 mOsm/kg
  • Plasma ketones– Positive
  • Metabolic acidosis– Increased anion gap
  • Serum bicarbonate <15 meq/L– Best initial investigation
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperamylasemia

Management of DKA

  • Admit to hospital assess for serum electrolytes and acid-base status
  • Replace fluids- 2-3 liters (10-20 mL/kg/hr) of normal saline should be administered over 1-3 hours. Subsequently 0.45% saline at 250-500 mL/hr. It can be changed to 5% glucose and 0.45% saline at 150–250 mL/h when plasma glucose reaches 250 mg/dL.
  • Administer IV short-acting insulin regular insulin. 0.1 units/kg of insulin should be administered immediately as a bolus dose. This is followed by an intravenous infusion of 0.1 units/kg. Serum potassium levels should be checked before initiating insulin. If the levels are high, then it has to be corrected and then insulin should be started.
  • The above measures should be continued until the serum glucose levels reach 150–200 mg/dL, and acidosis is resolved. Insulin infusion may be decreased to 0.02–0.1 units/kg per hour.
  • Long-acting insulin can be started when the patient starts eating.

questions.text: A patient was referred by a doctor to a radiologist for a CT scan and the doctor was given money for the referral. What is this unethical act called?
questions.solution:
This unethical act of receiving a commission for referring a patient is referred to as Dichotomy. 

Dichotomy is an unethical act wherein a doctor receives a gift, commission or money for referring, recommending, or procuring a patient for any medical, surgical or other treatments. Fee splitting is unethical in India.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for breast carcinoma. She now presents with painless swelling involving the arm as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image are suggestive of post-mastectomy lymphedema involving the upper limb.

Lymphoedema occurs when interstitial fluid accumulates due to defective lymphatic drainage. It is a common complication of breast cancer treatment involving axillary lymph node dissection and radiotherapy. Sentinel lymph node dissection (SLND) reduces the risk of lymphedema significantly.

Clinical signs and symptoms are observed in the ipsilateral arm. A significant increase in the limb size due to swelling is seen. Other symptoms are heaviness, tightness, numbness, tingling, limb fatigue, and reduced limb mobility.

Diagnosis is predominantly based on the clinical swelling of the arm. The girth of the affected arm >2 centimeters than the normal limb, a 200-mL or more increase in limb volume, or a 5% or greater limb volume change are other diagnostic criteria.

Management:

Limb elevation, elastic arm stockings, and pneumatic compression devices can help reduce swelling. 

Dry skin can be seen due to fluid accumulation, which can lead to cellulitis/skin infections. Using a low pH water-based moisturizer is helpful.

Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) by a therapist followed by simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) by the patient daily aids interstitial fluid evacuation.

Benzpyrones and flavonoids are some naturally occurring substances that may be of use to treat lymphedema.

Surgical options are lymphaticovenular anastomosis, liposuction, and debulking.

Other options:

Option B:   Stewart-Treves syndrome refers to lymphangiosarcoma seen in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy (more than 10 years). They present as single/multiple bluish-red skin and subcutaneous nodules. They can ulcerate and hemorrhage.

Option C: Axillary venous thrombosis or Paget-Schrotter disease is seen in patients doing rigorous exercise and in weightlifters. The subclavian vein is compressed at the thoracic outlet. Painful swelling of the arm is observed.

Option D: Cellulitis usually presents with an ulcer and the skin is erythematous, swollen, and painful. Fever, chills, and rigor follow.

questions.text: The following instrument is used to augment labour in a 28-year-old primigravida via low rupture of membranes. Identify this instrument.
questions.solution:
The given instrument is Kocher's artery forceps and is identified by the presence of a single tooth at the tip.

Kocher's artery forceps are used to achieve hemostasis by holding bleeding vessels. They are also used in low rupture of membranes to augment labour or for the surgical induction of labour. 

The difference between artery forceps and needle holders is in the edge and smoothness of corrugations. Artery forceps have smooth edges and single lined corrugations whereas, needle holders have rough edges and crossed lines forming square to diamond shaped corrugations.

questions.text: As per the WHO recommendation for AMTSL (active management of the third stage of labor), when should the oxytocin be administered?

choices.text: After 30 min of delivery of fetus
Within 1 min of delivery of fetus
Within 1 min of delivery of placenta
After 5 mins of delivery of placenta

questions.solution:
WHO guidelines for active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL) recommends oxytocin administration immediately (within 1 minute) after the delivery of the fetus.  Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV. It should be given after the delivery of the fetus and before the delivery of the placenta. 

AMTSL  guidelines recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonic (Oxytocin). Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in cesarean section and in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tonus assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women. Continuous monitoring of uterine tone is done every 15 minutes for 2 hours. If uterine atony is detected, a fundal massage is performed.

Uterine massage is not recommended routinely.

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor to decrease PPH. Delayed cord clamping is a less important component in this direction and similarly, cord traction is not as critical. Uterine massage does not form the main component of AMTSL.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient was detected to have a Hb-18 g/dl, hematocrit-54%, and an elevated erythropoietin level. Which of the following is the least likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Polycythemia vera is the least likely diagnosis as erythropoietin levels are normal or reduced in it.

Polycythemia means an increase in the number of red blood cells in the body. It is classified as

  • Primary polycythemia- occurs due to the mutations in the hematopoietic stem cells. Since the defect is in the hematopoietic stem cells, an increase in the white blood cells and platelets also can be seen. The erythropoietin levels are normal or decreased. Eg. Polycythemia vera
  • Secondary polycythemia- occurs due to an increase in the level of erythropoietin. This stimulates the production of RBCs. Since the hematopoietic stem cells are normal, the platelets and WBCs are normal. Important causes are:
    • Hypoxia due to chronic lung disease, high altitude, carbon monoxide poisoning
    • Autonomous production of erythropoietin in renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma, etc.
  • Relative (spurious) polycythemia- Here the red cell count or the hemoglobin count appears elevated due to a decrease in the plasma volume. It is commonly seen in dehydration.

questions.text: The plain X-ray shows a particular pathological change in ribs and is seen in:
questions.solution:
The X-ray depicts the inferior rib notching which is one of the findings in coarctation of the aorta.

The most common location of coarctation of the aorta is just beyond the origin of the left subclavian artery.

  • Plain radiograph findings:
    • A figure of 3 sign (Reverse 3): Contour abnormality of the aorta
  • Inferior rib notching: Roesler sign
    • Secondary to dilated intercostal collateral vessels which form as a way to bypass the coarctation and supply the descending aorta
    • The dilated and tortuous vessels erode the inferior margins of the ribs, resulting in notching.
    • Not seen in infancy (unusual in patients <5 years of age)
    • Usually, the 4th to 8th ribs are involved, 1st and 2nd ribs do not become notched.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents in December with the following lesion on the extensor aspect of the elbow. The lesions are associated with itching. He consumes alcohol and smokes around 9 cigarettes every day. When the doctor scratched the lesions, the scales initially increased. On successive removal of the scales, there was a glossy red membrane. On removal of the membrane, there were pinpoint bleeding spots. He says that similar lesions are also present on the trunk. All other features mentioned below can be found in this patient except
questions.solution:
The given image shows red scaly plaque with silvery-white fine scales, and the lesion on scratching shows Auspitz's sign on scratching. These features are suggestive of psoriasis in the patient. Pautrier's microabscess is a feature of mycosis fungoides.

Psoriasis is a chronic, inflammatory and proliferative condition of the skin that also involves various organ manifestations. 

Several factors play a role in the development of the disease. They can be streptococcal infections, medications like beta-blockers, non‐steroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and angiotensin‐converting enzymes, alcohol abuse, cigarette smoking, and psychological stress.

Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis and is seen in 80-90% of patients. The peak on occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash. The lesions are red, scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin. They can also be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring. They commonly appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

When the lesions are scratched, the scaling increases initially. The successive removal of scales usually reveals an underlying smooth, glossy red membrane. This membrane when removed shows small bleeding points. This finding is called Auspitz’s sign.

The nails may be involved in psoriasis. The nails grow quickly in patients with psoriasis. Involvement of nail matrix disease leads to pits, ridges, and grooves of the nail plate. Involvement of nail bed causes subungual oil drops, subungual hyperkeratosis, and distal onycholysis.

Histopathology will show the presence of hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, the disappearance of the granular layer, and epidermal hyperplasia. In the Malpighian layer, neutrophils may accumulate to form the characteristic spongiform pustules of Kogoj. Accumulation of neutrophils in the stratum corneum forms Munro microabscess. There is hyperplasia and elongation of rete ridges with dilated and tortuous blood vessels.

questions.text: Resistant hypertension is defined as?

choices.text: BP >160/90 mmHg with one anti hypertensive
BP >140/90 mmHg with one anti hypertensive
BP >160/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives
BP >140/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives

questions.solution:
Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure being persistently >140/90 mmHg despite taking three or more antihypertensive agents, including a diuretic.

Resistant hypertension is more common in patients aged >60 years than in younger patients. Resistant hypertension may be related to pseudohypertension (high office blood pressures and lower home blood pressures), nonadherence to therapy, and identifiable causes of hypertension including obesity and excessive alcohol intake.

questions.text: An anxious patient with a black mole over his back presents to the clinic for evaluation. All of the following features according to the ABCDE rule will point towards a diagnosis of melanoma in this patient except?
questions.solution:
D stands for diameter >6 mm and not depth > 6mm.

Melanoma:

The ABCDE of Melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape.

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill defined.

C : Color variegation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color.

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser).

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole.

questions.text:
A patient underwent a TAPP repair for an incarcerated left inguinal hernia. While fixing the mesh, tacks were accidentally placed below the iliopubic tract. On follow-up visits, the patient complained of persistent pain in his lateral thigh. Which of the following injury has most likely caused the pain?

TAPP - Transabdominal Preperitoneal
questions.solution:
Injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most likely cause of pain in the above scenario.

It can be injured in laparoscopic hernia repair. 

In laparoscopic TAPP repair, to reduce chances of nerve injury during mesh placement, tacks are ideally placed above the iliopubic tract (away from the triangle of pain which carries the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve, and the femoral nerve).

Other options:

Option A: Ilioinguinal nerve may be commonly injured during open hernia repair. It provides innervation to the groin and medial aspect of the thigh, the upper part of the scrotum, and the penile root.

Option B: Iliohypogastric nerve can be injured while making an incision in the right iliac fossa during hernia surgery. It mainly supplies the suprapubic skin.

Option C: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve (which supplies the skin over the upper anterior part of the thigh) lies in close relation to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. Injury to these also can cause loss of sensation over the thigh but these are less frequent.

 

 

Related Pearl: The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

It is bounded

  • Superio-medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Inferio-laterally by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

Related Pearl: The triangle of doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Femoral nerve
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: Identify the mode in USG.
questions.solution:
The USG image represents M-mode used for echocardiography. Echo intensity is represented as brightness and trace is swept across the screen so that the x-axis represents time.

Modes in USG:

  1. A mode – amplitude mode is used in ophthalmology and orbital biometry 
  2. B mode/grayscale - used for all routine applications
  3. M mode – echocardiography (motion)

The advantage of USG is that there is no radiation and it is portable. It is the safest radiological investigation in pregnancy. It is the preferred investigation for:

  • Gall bladder pathology
  • Cysts
  • Fluid collection like ascites, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion
  • Initial evaluation of jaundice

The disadvantage of USG is the operator dependence.

HIFU (high intensity focussed USG) is a therapeutic application of USG. It is useful for the treatment of fibroids. HIFU exploits the thermal effects of high-powered tightly-focused ultrasound beams so that very small target tissues can be heated and coagulated.
